subject: bts test
content: May I know how to create a binary tree in the test? Does it just use insert to create a binary tree.
i_answer: BinarySearchTree has constructors. In order to create a binary search tree, you need a typename T and a comparator (optional, the default one is std::less<T>). Just like how you want to create a vector of int (you use vector<int>), you can create a binary search tree in a similar way.. After you create one, you can insert nodes to the tree. You can also use the copy constructor to create another tree.

subject: were we supposed to include assert statements in our functions?
content: Did we just need them in our tests or in our functions as well? I have heard conflicting things and want to make sure. Thanks!
i_answer: In your non-test functions (so your functions in Matrix.cpp, Image.cpp, etc), you didn't need to assert anything. However, it is good practice to assert the invariants specified in the function's REQUIRES clause. While the autograder won't test your functions with inputs that break these invariants, it's possible for you to make implementation mistakes that break these invariants -- assert statements help you find these bugs!

subject: difference between return img.width and return img->width
content: Hi, I want to ask about the difference between -> and . operation. Can I do both. return img->width; and return img.width; ?. Are they the same effect? Thank you so much!
i_answer: The dot operator assumes that the name before the dot is an object and has attributes that it can access. The arrow operator assumes that the name before the arrow is a pointer to an object that has attributes it can access. Therefore, they are not interchangeable - precisely,. ```cpp. img->width. // is the same as. (*img).width. ```. If you see something saying that the arrow first "dereferences" the pointer then gets the attribute, this is what they mean. It looks at the object the pointer is pointing to and then grabs the desired attribute.. . To answer your question, yes, they have the same effect, but are used in different cases.

subject: Getting very large image for seam removal.
content: . void remove_vertical_seam(Image* img, const int seam[]) {.   Image* aux = new Image;.   Image_init(aux, MAX_MATRIX_WIDTH, MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT);.   for (int i = 0; i < Image_height(img); ++i) {.     for (int j = 0; j < Image_width(img); ++j) {.       if (j < seam[i]){.         Image_set_pixel(aux, i, j, Image_get_pixel(img, i, j));.       }.       if (j > seam[i]) {.         Image_set_pixel(aux, i, j-1, Image_get_pixel(img, i, j));.       }. .   }.   *img = *aux;.   delete aux;. }. }. . So we are trying to remove the seam of our image, but we seem to be getting an infinitely large image filled with 0 0 0 pixels. We aren't quite sure why we are getting such a large image, so any help would be appreciated..
i_answer: I think the problem is here: Image_init(aux, MAX_MATRIX_WIDTH, MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT); You would have to initialize aux to be the same height as the image and width should be 1 less than the image width since your taking out a seam

I'm just at a bit of a loss as to how to even approach debugging this. Does anyone have any sort of idea what could be wrong/ how to try and debug this?. . I know the FAQ says Crabster catches more edge cases but I've been working on this for hours with no progress or even a clue as to what is going wrong. . . Thanks, sorry for the late frantic post.

Take another look at the spec example of how carving works and double check all processing functions to prove to yourself that the functions are handling each edge case exactly as it is supposed to. Draw it out, may seem tedious but for some bugs this is the only way to find them.

subject: I think the style checks in the Makefile and in the autograder are different
content: Basically, in the autograder the `cpd` command is. . ```. pmd.sh cpd --minimum-tokens 100 --language cpp --failOnViolation true --files Matrix.cpp processing.cpp Image.cpp resize.cpp. ```. . Whereas in the Makefile the `$FILES` variable also includes the test files. . . Just in case anyone was running into something similar.

subject: Horses.ppm cost keeps timing out on autograder.
content: I would really like some help with identifying where my code is taking the longest. My code passes crabster.ppm very quickly, but horses.ppm times out on compute_vertical_cost_matrix. I suspect it might be my Matrix_min_value_in_row, which has two (non-nested) for loops, but only one of them will run in a given call. since the function is exclusive of column_end, i have an if-statement that runs a different loop if the column_end is exactly one less than the width of the matrix to allow me to compute cost for the second-to-last column of a cost matrix.. . If any instructor is able to check the code I submitted to the autograder, that would be super appreciated..
i_answer: Try using the perf utility, which should help you find exactly what function is causing the slowdown. Another possible reason you cannot run through horses.ppm is a memory leak. Make sure you search through all your functions, even ones that you don't suspect, to make sure that you deleted any objects you make in dynamic memory!

subject: Mismatched cost data after second row
content: hi. We are getting an assertion failure, because after the second row our cost matrix does not match the values of the correct matrix. seemingly always less than the correct value. We have been rethinking and looking over the function, but can't seem to figure out what we are missing. Any help would be greatly appreciated!
i_answer: I believe the matrix_min_value_in_row function isn't inclusive of the end column. So for example, when you are at the first column and  want to consider columns 0,1, your start_col would be 0 and your end_col would be 2.

"Matrix *mat = new Matrix;". to make the matrix. and . "delete mat;". to remove it.

subject: Long Lines

i_answer: Yes you can, but you may notice that this will increase the length of the function (so you may have long functions). If you cannot fix it by simply splitting it into 2 lines, think if it is reasonable to take some code out from the function and make the code another helper function.

subject: Test cases
content: Do we need to write test cases for every function?
i_answer: Your test cases will be used on known faulty programs to see if your test cases catch the bugs of the programs. If the faulty programs have a bug with a specific function that you don't test, you may get points off for your test cases.

subject: are we required to comment our code?

subject: mutation test suites
content: Hello, . . About the tests we write for the mutation tests suites, are we also supposed to intentionally write test cases that would fail on proper code, but work for the buggy implementation? . . Say for example something like declaring a matrix with an invalid width/height value?.
i_answer: You are supposed to write tests using valid input and compare the output of the functions to the expected output using assert statments. If the output of the functions is not what it should be, the assert statments should fail, successfully flagging a buggy program as being inaccurate.

subject: Autograder error "a function-definition is not allowed here before '{' token"

subject: Running into an error with processing find_minimal_vertical_seam
content: find seam...processing_public_tests.exe: processing_public_tests.cpp:162: void test_find_seam(const int*, int, std::string): Assertion `array_equal(seam, seam_correct, n)' failed.. . Anyone else running into this error? No clue on how to fix this
i_answer: This means that your find_minimal_vertical_seam function is not working properly. The assertion `array_equal(seam, seam_correct, n)' failed because the seam array edited by your function does not match the correct seam array. I would recommend either using a visual debugger or printing out the arrays in order to view the differences between your array and the expected one.

subject: How to test const int matrix_at function
content: I created a new matrix mat and initialize/fill it. . Then I created the const int matrix like this:. . Matrix const *matc = mat;. then calling matrix_at function like:. . *Matrix_at(matc, row, column). . . . . Getting this error when I try to test the const int matrix_at functions, not sure if it is how I tested it, or if it is my const int matrix_at function.. . ==75984==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: attempting double-free on 0x0001057f4800 in thread T0:    #0 0x102a26330 in wrap__ZdlPv+0x74 (libclang_rt.asan_osx_dynamic.dylib:arm64e+0x4e330)    #1 0x102429028 in test_matrix_at_const() Matrix_tests.cpp:179    #2 0x1024191dc in TestCase::run(bool) unit_test_framework.h:420    #3 0x10241c228 in TestSuite::run_tests(int, char**) unit_test_framework.h:509    #4 0x10242a04c in main Matrix_tests.cpp:291    #5 0x1024f9088 in start+0x204 (dyld:arm64e+0x5088). . . . . . . . .
i_answer: A `double-free` error means that you are trying to delete something that you have already deleted. Check to make sure that you don't have two delete statements for the same function, or that you aren't deleting something in your `Matrix.cpp` functions.

subject: Image_get_pixel taking too long to run
content: . My Image_get_pixel is drastically slowing down my code. All of our processing public tests are passing, however very slowly (crabster takes two minutes, and each removed seam in horses takes a minute). Is anyone else experiencing this issue? I don't know how we can further simplify our Image_get_pixel function. Getting rid of the asserts isn't helping, either. I'm afraid that our public tests will time out in autograder..
i_answer: It might not even be that Image_get_pixel() is taking that long. It could be that you're calling it too often by iterating over pixels that you don't have to iterate over, or you're iterating over a bunch of pixels multiple times.. . I also don't recommend removing the assert statements, since that is likely not the issue, and it should help in debugging.

subject: horse test time
content: Hi! . My horse public_tests have been running for at least 10-15 minutes now. Should I stop it and troubleshoot why or is it normal?It is the seam_carve 300x382 test that I am stuck on.
i_answer: Yes, you should troubleshoot it because the autograder only allows 30-60 seconds per test. Horse typically takes longer than other tests but it shouldn’t be that long.. . Sometimes you might be calling helper functions meant to "respect the interface" within the actually interface they are meant to protect, which is not the use for then. This can really take up a ton of time if the function is called a bunch - think about how much longer it takes for your computer to access a value of class through a function then just by directly calling it (it can be around 2-3x slower!) That being said, do NOT go and replace these functions by just calling the values in places you aren't supposed to (eg other interfaces) to just save time. It's poor practice and the autograder will complain.

subject: Seam_carve test for crabster & horses
content: Hello,. . I am having an issue where I run the processing_public_tests and seam_carve() is failing for crabster. If you include a third argument, it actually has to be a comparator (more on what that is later this semester).. . To fix this, see if you can use the Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row() function.

subject: crabster find seam
content: Hi! I am failing the crabster find_seam test. I went through the code 1000 times now, but I can´t find any bugs etc. Does anyone have an advice what I should be looking out for? Common mistakes, edge cases etc.. Thank you so much!
i_answer: If you’ve already followed your code through the debugger and it does what you expect (which ends up being wrong), then perhaps your understanding of the seam function’s intended behavior is wrong.. . I misunderstood this function at first as well. As detailed in the spec here, the bounds for finding the minimum cost actually change depending on which column the minimum was in for the previously parsed row. Although the diagram in the spec does not deviate much from the initial minimum being in the 3rd column, it would be possible to have a minimum seam cross in a diagonal direction across an image.. . Here is another diagram illustrating this: . The circles are the minimum value found in the inclusive bounds, and the boxes are the corresponding new bounds for the next row's analysis.. . Another common mistake is not using bounds that span from n-1 to n+2 to account for the fact that the matrix minimum column function has an inclusive lower bound and and exclusive upper bound. . I hope this helps!. .

subject: Print test basic fails
content: Each time I run the test the numbers that should be pixel color values change. I think this has to do with my second image init function but can not figure out where the problem is. Am I correct in assuming this is the problem because it prints the correctly?
i_answer: Your intuition on where the issue is possible. It seems like the numbers being outputted are not even close to the integers (0 or 255) that we expect them to be, however they are not pointers (these will print starting with 0x). This seems like the image's r, g, and b channel matrices are never properly being set.. . Make sure that when you transfer `is` stream values to the matrices, you are dereferencing the `Matrix_at()` value. `Matrix_at()` returns a pointer to the integer you want to change, so just performing `is >> Matrix_at(r_channel, x, y)` will not change the actual value associated with the matrix cell at row x and column y.. . I also recommend placing a breakpoint in your image_init() and image_print() functions so you can follow the program flow line by line and monitor where variable values are not what you expect.. . Hope this helps.

subject: Conceptual confusion Vert Cost Matrix
content: . Right now I am having issues with computing the vertical cost matrix. When. . . When I do Matrix_min_value_in_row(mat, row above, left column (inclusive), right column (exclusive) ). . . . . I want to include that right (green, 2940) column so I end my bound at the next one over (blue square) because of exclusivity. However, because of that correction that means Matrix_at goes OOB (assertion flag) because I add one additional to column_end. I don't really understand why min_value_in_row is exclusive at the end nor how I would fix it. .
i_answer: Your understanding the vertical cost  function is correct, in that you need to have bounds i-1 and i+2. However, when you are on the left edge of the matrix, you’re bound i-1 will OOB and on the right side i+w2 will too. Try using logic to determine if you are at a first or last column and adjusting the bounds accordingly. You will need to do this every time you compute a cost.. . I hope this helps!

subject: energy matrix
content: How do you compute an energy matrix if there is only 1 row or column?
i_answer: This case shouldn't really even happen because if there's only 1 row or column and you're running a seam carve, the end height/width would be 0, which isn't allowed. However, this isn't part of the requires clause of compute_energy_matrix(), so it's not a bad idea to check for this case.. . 1. Fill it with zeros. This should give you a 1xn or nx1 matrix with all 0's.. . 2. Compute the energy for each non-border pixel. All pixels are on the border, so we can skip this.. . 3. Find the maximum energy so far (which is 0), and use it to fill the border pixels. Again, all of the pixels are on the border, so we set them to 0.. . In the end, the energy matrix should just be filled with 0's.

subject: Here's a tip for using GIMP with vscode

subject: Changing MAX_MATRIX_WIDTH/HEIGHT for tests
content: Say I want to write test cases that will check my funcions are working when matrix_height/width are equal to the MAX_MATRIX_WIDTH/HEIGHT. I was thinking making the maxes smaller in matrix.h in order to make it run faster, or should I just keep it 500x500 since the autograder will use those values?
i_answer: You should keep it 500 and 500 - I don't see how changing these would make the program run faster. When the program creates the initial data array in `Matrix`, it shouldn't run slower depending on the size of the array, since it isn't initializing anything in that array yet. It's just sectioning off an area of memory that's marked for your to use later. Unless your system is really strapped for memory, initializing a 250000 size array shouldn't take much more time than a 250 size array.. . If you do have an efficiency problem, I would suggest looking into your getter and setter functions (`Matrix_at`, down the line `Image_get_pixel`, `Image_set_pixel`). These functions are used often and need to be fast for every other function to be fast.

subject: Processing.cpp seam carve runtime error
content: Hello, . I have a problem of my processing.cpp. When I run the crabster test of processing_public_tests.exe, the terminal shows:. Testing crabster seam carve 50x45…processing.cpp:73:13: runtime error: signed integer overflow: -1094795781 * -1094795781 cannot be represented in type ‘int’ SUMMARY: UndefinedBehaviorSanitizer: undefined-behavior processing.cpp:73:13 in. . So, what’s problem of my code?. Thank you!.
i_answer: Typically when the runtime encounters large numbers like this, you are looking at or trying to use initialized data. Check that your `init`, `get`, and `fill` functions are doing what they are supposed to be doing and defining bounds/values correctly.. . It may also help to set up the debugger to see which variable is being assigned the `-1094795781 * -1094795781` value so you can pinpoint what is causing the problem.

subject: How do you copy pixels into a new image; RemoveVerticalSeam
content: I understand how to copy the new image back to the original one, but not how to copy pixels into a new image. I am clueless.
i_answer: You can use `Image_set_pixel` on the new image with the image you got from the old image. For example,. ```cpp. Image* img = new Image;. Image * img2 = new Image;. Image_init(img, 1, 1);. Image_init(img2, 1, 1);. Image_fill(img, {255, 255, 255});. Image_set_pixel(img2, 0, 0, Image_get_pixel(img, 0, 0));. ```

content: Hello Instructors,. . My partner: Benny Huang (bennyh). Me: Tiffany Tang (tifftang). . subject: Matrix_init error
content: What could the error "Use of deallocated memory" indicate in Matrix_init? My partner and I never got this error until trying to run resize.
i_answer: From your most recent autograder submission, I would take a look at your seam_carve_width function. It looks like you allocate dynamic memory for energy/cost matrices once at the beginning of the function, but then attempt to deallocate them in every iteration of your while loop. I would suggest moving those deletes to the end of the function (after the while loop). Otherwise, you are trying to reuse these matricies in the next iteration of the while loop, even though they have been deallocated.

subject: resize.cpp error when using argv[n]
content: I'm getting this error when I try to declare an `istream` or `ostream` using`argv[n]`. . no instance of constructor `std::__1::basic_ostream::basic_ostream [with _CharT=char, _Traits=std::__1::char_traits]` matches the argument list
i_answer: You shouldn't need to decarle streams with anything on their initialization statement. For file streams, you would do:. ```cpp. ifstream file_in;. file_in.open(filename);. ```. For string streams, you would just do:. ```cpp. ostringstream expected;. expected << // data you would feed in to the string stream. ```. If you put something on that initialization line, the computer will try to pass it to a constructor that may or may not exist and then spit out that error.

subject: Resize output creates new file instead of failing
content: If I understand the specification correctly, in resize.cpp, we are supposed to print out the message "Error opening file: ..." when you cannot open the input or output file with the given name. Is there a way to make this output fail instead of creating a new file so that the error message will be printed?
i_answer: When the files cannot be opened or the argc is not the correct numbers, you are supposed to print out error messages and return with the error status (so the program is terminated). If you do not return in time, the program will keep running, and you may create new files.

subject: test_remove_seam failing when the results are the same
content: I'm having trouble testing processing.cpp, specifically right now I caught on test_remove_seam. The problem seems to be the same as @1105 but I haven't been able to get any headway from that.. . Essentially my results and the results in the files seem to be correct, I ran. . $sdiff dog_removed.correct.ppm dog_removed.out.ppm. . and, as seen in the picture below, the 2 PPM files are the same.. . . . However, on line 178 of processing_public_tests.cpp,. . . assert(Image_equal(removed_img, removed_img_correct));. . . still fails. I used my debugger to see what the two values being compared were, I found that removed_img_correct was a 5x5 file while my result was a 4x5. They seem to be different images? I'm not sure what's going on here. The debugger menu (right before line 78):. . . . . . Shouldn't removed_img_correct be a 4x5 size image, since the size shrank? What's wrong with my output here? I saw there was something about this in the FAQ but I just don't know what to do here, my Image_init seems fine. (I made an autograder submission earlier today as well if it helps). .
i_answer: Ok so I finally figured this out... after a lot of digging :P Putting this here to explain what I did wrong and maybe someone else did wrong as well.. . test_remove_seam creates the correct image struct (through load_image) using YOUR image_init function. Specifically, it uses the version that uses an istream. The issue with my code was there. In my situation, I attempted to directly save a value into img's height and width using (*img).height, instead of using the other image_init function (that inputs height width values) instead.. . Anyways hoped this helped anyone else in the same position as me.

subject: Couple questions about resize.cpp
content: For resize, I think I have the first few steps correct, but then I'm a little lost on the rest. I use ifstream and open the file using argv[1], create a new image, and then call Image_init to initialize the height and width. After that I then close the file. Is this the point at which I close the file or do I wait until the very end?. . My thought was to create if and else-if statements to initialize the image based on if there are 4 or 5 arguments. And then I called seam_carve, but then the program just seems to stop after that (when I go through it with my debugger), so it never makes it to Image_print. Is there something that I am doing wrong or missing?
i_answer: You can close the input file after initializing the image. I don't think whether there are 4 or 5 arguments should change how you initialize the image. What it does change though, is what parameters you call seam_carve with. In the case where there is a height argument, you pass that argument to seam_carve. In the case where there is not a height argument (argc = 4), you pass the Image_height of the input image to seam_carve. I am not sure why your program seems to stop. I would take a careful look at your if-then logic.

How do I go about fixing this?

subject: remove_vertical_seam function does not pass public test
content: Hello!It is already late but I have really been sitting on it for the whole day. The function looks very right to me regardless of how many times and in how many ways I am going through it, and I read through all advice on Piazza. Can someone help me to look over the code? Is this something that instructors can help with when I only post my code to instructors? Please disregard this if I am not allowed to share my code at all but I am also running out of options :(. . . Thank you!Best,. Jenni. . .
i_answer: Consider this case when seam[i] == Matrix_width. What will happen in your inner loops when copying over pixels from the original image to the smaller image with the seam removed? Your loop copying pixels after the seam may run into trouble.. .

subject: How to Find the Original Width and Height of the input image
content: In resize.cpp, we need to compare the new images width and height to the original image's width and height. How do we find the old images width and height since it is in the file itself?
i_answer: After running Image_init with your file input stream on the image object you created, you can use the member functions Image_width and Image_height to access the dimensions of the original image.

subject: How to use my own pictures
content: How can I use the project to edit my own pictures just like Jon Beaumont in his slides?
i_answer: You can use an online jpg or png to ppm format and save it to your directory, and pass it into resize when you run it.. . Beware, most of the online ppm converters use a P6 ppm format. You can use this converter I found to convert the image to the P3 ppm format our program uses: . . https://thomasebsmith.github.io/ppm-converter/

subject: Istream not being read in when executing resize.exe
i_answer: resolved.

subject: AddressSanitizer memory leak issue with remove vertical, thank you for helping
content: Hello, my partner and I are continually running into a sanitizer memory leak issue that we are now stuck on. Below is a photo of the error, but in our vertical remove seam we are deleting any objects made with dynamic memory so we are confused. Thanks again.
i_answer: You are setting ptr = img2, meaning that these two pointers point to the same memory address. Then at the end of the function, you delete both ptr and img2 which point to the same memory address, effectively causing a double delete. . . I would consider whether you need both ptr and img2 in this function.

subject: runtime error undefined behavior for processing_public_tests
content: Hello, I'm getting this runtime error when I run my processing public tests.exe. I've checked the bounds of my matrix_at function as well as double checked that my Image_set_pixel function works properly using test cases. I don't know what the issue is, it would be awesome if I could have some input.
i_answer: It seems like one of your processing functions is indexing out of bounds when it calls image_set_pixel which calls Matrix_at. I would recommend adding asserts in your Matrix_at and Image_set_pixel aligned with the requires clauses to debug and trace back which processing function is indexing out of bounds.

subject: resize.cpp output
content: Hi! Our output for resize.cpp is completely wrong and we are not sure where our code went wrong. I have attached a picture of our driver and a picture of the output that it results in.
i_answer: I see 2 issues here. First off, you're reading "int outputHeight = atoi(argv[4])". without any bounds checking. What if there are only 4 arguments total? Then this will access memory that shouldn't be accessed, and it might crash, or it might run with undefined behavior. You should be checking whether you have enough arguments before reading in the arguments.. . Secondly, it looks like you're printing the image before making any modifications to it. You should be printing it after you've done seam_carve_width() (and also seam_carve_height() if it needs to be done).

subject: Traversal by pointer
content: I'm trying to do the traversal by pointer for Matrix_column. It's giving me the error of a value of type "const int *" cannot be used to initialize an entity of type "int *". I'm not sure how else to initialize a pointer that points to the data array. Edit: I want to change this function so it doesn't use a loop but I don't know how to go about that.
i_answer: You should not be using for loops in matrix_column, matrix_row, or matrix_at. There is a way to do them without loops, there's just a little math involved. If you use loops your code will time out in the autograder for the processing tests usually

subject: error message for resize
content: for resize.cpp. the spec says "If any of these are violated, use the following lines of code (literally) to print an error message.". cout << "Usage: resize.exe IN_FILENAME OUT_FILENAME WIDTH [HEIGHT]\n"     << "WIDTH and HEIGHT must be less than or equal to original" << endl;. . are we supposed to replace IN_FILENAME OUT_FILENAME WIDTH [HEIGHT] with the actual values or why is height in []?

subject: In the autograder it says I timed out.
i_answer: Normally this happens because of too many for loops in matrix.cpp. I think you should try to another way to do Matrix_fill_border specifically. There is no need to have 2 double/nested for loops, all you need is 2 single for loops.. . - 1 for loop for filling the first and last column (this can be done in 1 loop). - 1 for loop for filling the first and last row (this can be done in another separate for loop). . That should fix the issue

subject: Image public tests

i_answer: To find the issue you'll need to use your debugger. I would set a breakpoint on the first line of the from and to stream test, then go line by line keeping track of your variables to see which function is going wrong

subject: is the grading of our tests cases just what we see on the autograder?
Unknown memory address error when running processing_public_tests

My column_of_min_value_in_row function is passing all of my private and public tests, so I'm not sure what the issue could be. . .
i_answer: The problem does not seem to be with your Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row. Somewhere in your processing.cpp, you are likely passing it values that are out of bounds of the matrix. I would suggest looking where this function is used in processing.cpp and make sure there are no edge cases where you pass it invalid input. I would also suggest adding assert statments for the required clause of Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row if you haven't already.

subject: How to test int* Matrix_at  vs const int* Matrix_at

subject: Git Error
content: Hi, I am having issues with git pull and git push.. . .
i_answer: It looks like you have changes added to the staging area that you have not commited. Either commit your changes and run git push or run git reset to unstage them and git restore to revert your changes to the files before running git pull.

subject: Does a maximum of 50 test cases mean we are allowed 50 test cases or 49 test cases?
content: Does a maximum of 50 test cases mean we are allowed 50 test cases or 49 test cases?
i_answer: Should be 50. I will say (and i think the spec says) that you shouldn't need 50 test cases to catch everything - pay attention to *what* you're testing more than *how much* you're testing.

subject: Respecting the interface
content: Just to clarify, to respect the interface are we not supposed to do something like mat->height in any of the test files?
i_answer: Correct

subject: seam_carve error
content: While running our tests for processing.cpp, our debugger showed us that all of our tests passed for the dog image, but when we tested crabster, the seam carve test fails, this is really confusing us because it worked for the first test and we're not sure where how we should continue from this point..
i_answer: Maybe try having a look at your seam_carve function and see how many times it carries out its carving action. For dog.ppm it only requires you to use seam carve once as it goes from 5x5 to 4x5 but for crabster you need to run the carving algorithm multiple times. Hope this helps in some way!

subject: Accounting for images with a width of 1
content: Should our compute_vertical_cost_matrix and find_minimal_vertical_seam be written to account for images with a width of 1? I see that remove_vertical_seam "requires" that the Image points to a valid Image with a width >=2, and it would make sense that this would apply to computing the vertical cost and finding the minimal vertical seam as well, given that an image with a width of one only has one seam that could be removed. But, it is not explicitly stated in the requires clause, so I figured it was worth asking to double-check.. . Thanks in advance!

subject: test processing and resize

i_answer: You are not graded on your tests for these functions but it may be a good idea for you to test them outside of the public tests to catch any extra bugs that might cause your program to fail the private tests.

subject: Dog.ppm not opening in autograder

My inequalities for the error checking were > instead of >=

subject: compute_energy_matrix
content: Just to clarify, for compute_energy_matrix, do we fill each non-border pixel with it's calculated energy, or do we leave the non-border pixels filled with 0, and only calculate the energy to find the max value, which we then use to fill the border-pixels?
i_answer: You first loop through the non-border pixels and calculate their energies, keeping a variable for the max energy. Then, once your loop is done, you set all of the borders to the max value.

subject: Autograder processing_public_tests horses bad_alloc error
content: I'm getting a bad_alloc error in the processing_public_tests horses section on autograder. I've seen other Piazza posts where the solution is to make sure that all objects created in dynamic memory with the new keyword are deleted. I've checked this an I'm still getting the error when I submit my code. Is there another source of this error that I should check for?
i_answer: Based on your autograder submit, it seems like your test_matrix_init function in Matrix_tests.cpp and your test_get_pixel_edge function in Image_tests.cpp are leaking memory. Same goes for your resize.cpp in line 23. Make sure you are reading where the autograder memory leak outputs are directing you towards, the address sanitizer contains useful information in tracking down memory leaks.

subject: Wrong output for image_print
content: After running the image_public_test, I can't seem to get the correct output. I coutted the statements to show you my output in the terminal; if I place the fout outside of the loop it doesn't work because the variables aren't in scope. How can I fix this? In general, it's giving me the wrong values for the pixels as well; the public test is red, green /n blue, white but mine is blue n/ white n/ blue n/ white.. printyerrors.png
i_answer: You do not need to use cout or fout in this function. You should use the provided output stream parameter, "os". For example, you should use it in the following way:. . . os << red << " " << green << " " << blue << " " << endl;

subject: Runtime error: signed integer overflow
content: . Not sure what is causing this . . . .
i_answer: Signed integer overflows are typically caused by getter functions trying to access uninitialized data (unless you have really big numbers in your data) - check that your fill, init, and get functions are all declaring the bounds of data as you expect and getting the correct locations.

subject: Image_init: how do I read in a temporary pixel?

i_answer: Use the set pixel function. . Is this in the Image_init() function when reading an image from a file?. You will need to read in the first few chunks and set them as the width and height of the image, then use for loops to iterate through the remaining chunks which represent the r g and b values. Once you get the r, g, and b you can use the set pixel function.

subject: resize.cpp

subject: Matrix_at() Out of Bounds Checking
content: Do we have to make sure that our Matrix_at function and unit test guard against going out of bounds the scope of the Matrix(width and height, not MAX_WIDTH and MAX_HEIGHT)?. . If so, how should we handle the cases in which they do go out of bounds, would we instead return a pointer that points to the closes to valid spot in a matrix?
i_answer: Take a careful look at the requires clause for `Matrix_at`. If an input violates the requires clause, you don't need to worry about handling it at all.. ```. // REQUIRES: mat points to a valid Matrix. //           0 <= row && row < Matrix_height(mat). //           0 <= column && column < Matrix_width(mat). //. ```

subject: Testing Processing.cpp
content: How do we actually test our functions in processing so we know where things went wrong? Currently running the processing public tests just tells me that an assertion in image_init has failed but it doesn't tell me what part of processing is wrong, or any other insight. . . I know we are supposed to set up CAEN but what does that actually mean? Is it a website that we submit our files too? is it a command that we run that would give us more insight as to where our program went wrong? Thanks so much!
i_answer: CAEN is the computing services team at UMichigan, and they have a platform/environment set up for you to develop on computers and laptops across Michigan. We use that environment as a "ground zero" since we run the autograder using the same environment/configuration.. . As for a command to figure out what went wrong, I would highly recommend having your visual debugger on hand, since you can see the variables and objects during the runtime of the program.

subject: Seam[] type not allowing for it to be added to

subject: Test Cases Involving fstream
content: I am testing my image_init on fstream. I am able to pass an input file stream to init and output file stream to print. However, how do I compare the two files (i.e., the files created by print and the correct file)? I tried using ASSERT_TRUE(Image_equal(img1, img)) where img is the original file and img1 is what I printed after initializing but it didn't work.

Using the std::istringstream and std::ostringstream from the #include <cstdlib> header, we can convert these stream's contents to strings and compare the strings. If you find the slides for lecture 7 here, pages 20-22 show the usage of these streams for testing. Hope this helps!

subject: Errors
content: I keep getting these errors in my Image functions, and I'm not sure how to resolve them. Additionally, I'm not really sure how to implement a pointer traversal, or if I should just do a regular nested for loop.. ptrerror1.png. incompints.png
i_answer: For the first error, it doesn't look like you're using pointer traversal correctly. Your stepper var should be an integer that is added to the pointer to the first element in the array.. . You can read more on pages 26 and 27 in lecture 4's slides [here.](https://drive.google.com/drive/u/2/folders/1k81KJg0yGFnqn9vhZqlykjaMzZ0b2Mok). . For your second error, `img-›red_channel.data = red` isn't working for a couple of reasons.. . One, `img->red_channel` gives a pointer to the red_channel matrix. You want to dereference this pointer in order to actually modify anything in that object. Also, I'm assuming `red` is an integer. `red_channel` is of course an integer array, and you cannot assign that a value of an integer.. . Second, although there are other issues with this line as explained above, you do not want to be accessing the .data array from the channels directly. This is breaking the interface of Matrix since `red_channel` is a Matrix. You will want to use the Matrix_at() functions to set a particular value in this channel.. . Hope this helps!

subject: command line args resize
content: Hello, quick question for the resize.cpp file regarding it accepting the command line arguments and other file reading/writing details. Am I allowed to assume that the arguments will always be passed in the order given by the example? Does the file I am writing to need to be created before resize runs or would resize create the file? How do I account for the directory that the files resize is reading from and writing to? Should I just assume that they are in the same directory as the program?
i_answer: I think you can assume the arguments will always be passed in the order given by the example (I think they would include that in the error checking section if it was necessary).. The file you are writing to does not have to be created before running resize.. Assuming you are using fstream, the directory that you are reading and writing from depends on the input. If the input is a file path, you will read and write to the directory/file specified by the file path. If the input is just a filename, you will read and write to the same directory as the program. You don't have to account for the directory inside of your program.

subject: Assert Failing
content: I get the correct ppm files for dog, horses, and crabster files. However, when I include . . column < Matrix_width(mat)); in my Matrix_at functions or. column < Image_width(img)); in my Image_set_pixel/Image_get_pixel, they all fail. . I believe I narrowed it down to my processing.cpp file, the only assert I pass is if it is column <= width, but I am not sure when I am passing in a column that is equal to the width. . . . . . .
i_answer: I would recommend taking a very close look at your processing.cpp functions. The row and column bounds in your for loops might be the issue. Be extra careful since some of the processing functions require you to access matrix and image coordinates to the left right above and below of the current element (like with compute_energy_matrix). . . Also, if you set a breakpoint at the start of the processing_public_tests you can step through the code until you see the error, then you will know that the code you just stepped through is an area that is passing in incorrect row/col pairs.. . subject: resize runs error-free in XCode but not in terminal
content: When I run this in terminal, it runs into this error. However, when I run it in XCode by editing the scheme and passing in these arguments, it runs error-free and creates a file with the specified dimensions, but the image looks very wonky. Since building in XCode does not catch this error, I can't use the debugger.. Does anybody know why this would be the case and how I would go about debugging this?. Also I did make sure to "make resize.exe" right before this command.. . Update: I split the assert statement into 5 assertions and found out it's failing column_start < column_end.. . I then put a breakpoint here. When I run it in XCode it should stop here since it fails the assert but it skips right over it.
i_answer: When you run your code in XCode, does XCode rebuild it first? If so, it's possible XCode is removing your assert statements from the final build with a compiler argument like -DNDEBUG, which is why your asserts are being skipped in the debugger. Setting XCode to produce "Debug" builds (instead of "Release" ones) might fix this.. In ambiguous situations like this one, I recommend you try building and running your code on CAEN, as that is the closest environment to the autograder's. Hope this helps!

subject: fails for public test but works when tested seperately
content: so I get 2 errors for the public test for two of my functions, the print and the row one, however when I tested them seperately with the same conditions in the int main() of a different cpp file, I get the correct answer. For some reason it is only giving a wrong value when the matrix_public_test.exe file is executed. Can someone say why this is happening?
i_answer: The root cause is in your `Matrix_at` implementation. It appears to treat `row` and `column` as starting from 1 even though they actually start from 0. When `row == 0`, and `column == 0`, we're referring to the valid top left cell of a matrix.. . (How do we find this root cause? Your `Matrix_print` printed `42 1`, which suggests that the matrix's width got set to 42 even though it got initialized to 1. Where could this have come from? Most likely line 49 of Matrix_public_test, where we have the most relevant appearance of 42. How did that end up setting the width instead? You might have stepped before of the `data` array and ended up overwriting the width instead. **You can verify all of this by setting a breakpoint on that line 49 and stepping into `Matrix_at` in the debugger.**)

A false positive means that your code is reporting a bug where one does not exist. So far for me that has always meant that my test code had an issue in it.. Hope this helps.

subject: Some errors I'm having
content: I keep getting some errors that happen pretty repeatedly throughout my function. For starters, in my image_fill function, it won't let me manipulate the value of img->red_channel.data into color.r, renamed red for simplicity. Also, I'm not sure my pointer for loop is working properly, I am aware that I can't use regular ints like width and height, but what do I use instead? Also, do I index the pointer at 0? Thanks.. ptrerror1.png. incompints.png. Here's my Image.cpp file.. Image.cpp
i_answer: For your pointer for loop, remember that you can use pointer arithemetic to help you here. Your pointer should start by pointing to an address in memory that you want to start looking at, not the value 0. For example, if you wanted to start your loop at index (2, 3), you would have a pointer pointing to that element. . If you wanted your loop to end at index (2, 5), you'd want to go until your pointer is less than the address of that index. More information here: https://eecs280staff.github.io/notes/04_Arrays.html#array-indexing I'd check out the traversal by pointer section!. For your image errors, it looks like you're setting image->red_channel.data(which is an array of ints) to a single integer, which is where the error comes from. You'll need to set a specific element in the matrix to that value. (I'd reccomend using your matrix_at function!)

subject: Matrix_row problem
content: For Matrix_row, our thought process behind this was to find the distance between the pointer given and mat->data. Then, to find the row, we did the distance / mat->width. We are passing the public tests for Matrix_row, but not our own personal tests, and we can't seem to pinpoint the issue using the debugger. Any thoughts on what could be the issue?
i_answer: According to your autograder submission from the time, you mixed up the row and height numbers between `Matrix_init` and `Matrix_at` in your test. By calling `Matrix_init(mat, 3, 4)`, you initialized `mat` to have a _width of 3_ and a _height of 4_. This means it has 3 _columns_ and 4 _rows_, so the valid columns are 0, 1, 2, while the valid rows are 0, 1, 2, 3.. . Then, you did `Matrix_at(mat, 0, 3)`, which takes row 0 and column 3. `mat` does not have a column 3 (only 0, 1, and 2), so the 3 was out-of-bounds.. . Long story short, the ordering of the parameters in `Matrix_init` and `Matrix_at` are effectively swapped. For some `Matrix_init(mat, x, y)`, `Matrix_at(mat, a, b)` must satisfy `a

subject: UB check problem and double free or corruption problem
content: In autograder, there is a problem shown in autograder called corruption or double free in the matrix_test. We are confused about why this problem occurred. It looks like this: . *** Error in `./Matrix_tests.exe': double free or corruption (out): 0x0000000000c853c0 ***. . Also, we have another problem in UB check in matrix_test and already delete all the new matrix created. It looks like this: . ==91==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: heap-buffer-overflow on address 0x7faea0207a48 at pc 0x000000426be6 bp 0x7ffd60cc8780 sp 0x7ffd60cc8770. . Thank you so much for your help and time!
i_answer: `heap-buffer-overflow` typically means your program is trying to access heap memory beyond the end of a chunk of heap memory that it owns. Take a closer look at the address sanitizer's error (from the submission timestamped at 9:26 PM)---the first lines include a stack trace taken at the instant the illegal memory access occurred. Line 4 ends in "Matrix.cpp:23", so it tells you that line 23 in Matrix.cpp caused the illegal memory access. How could that line have led your program to access memory past the end of a chunk it owns?. . By comparing the program's output during the UB check and that during the double-free/corruption test run, you can tell that both errors happened inside the same test case, so they are probably related. By fixing the UB problem, you will probably fix the double-free/corruption error as well.

subject: Autograder Problems

The error is said to be on lines 120 and 131 in Matrix.cpp. (AKA in functions Matrix_fill() and const int Matrix_at(), the arithmetic/math particularly). . Error message: . Running test: test_image_basic. Matrix.cpp:131:30: runtime error: signed integer overflow: -1094795586 * -1094795586 cannot be represented in type 'int'. Matrix.cpp:120:19: runtime error: signed integer overflow: 2 * -1094795586 cannot be represented in type 'int'. AddressSanitizer:DEADLYSIGNAL. =================================================================. ==4081==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: SEGV on unknown address 0x7fd207f81e08 (pc 0x5559d52d580e bp 0x7fff6347a1c0 sp 0x7fff6347a100 T0). ==4081==The signal is caused by a READ memory access..     #0 0x5559d52d580d in Image_get_pixel(Image const*, int, int)

subject: Get_pixel: unsure how to return a pixel? Set_pixel: confused as to the difference in code?
content: Hihi, . . I've been digging through multiple Piazza posts on the topic and wanted to reach out for specific help. As I'm working on the Image.cpp file, I have encountered an obvious issue where my code for the image_get_pixel and image_set_pixel function are relatively the same. The only difference I understand is having to return a pixel (which I'm struggling to figure out) and returning nothing with the void function. I know the question may seem vague, but I would appreciate some clarification and potential guidance on this. I have attached my code for the two functions below. Thank you!. . . // REQUIRES: img points to a valid Image. //           0 <= row && row < Image_height(img). //           0 <= column && column < Image_width(img). // EFFECTS:  Returns the pixel in the Image at the given row and column.. Pixel Image_get_pixel(const Image* img, int row, int column) {.   assert(img->width && img->height);.   assert(0 <= row && row < Image_height(img));.   assert(0 <= column && column < Image_width(img)); . .   // Creates a new Pixel struct object by reading each of the red, green,.   // and blue matrices..   Pixel color;.   color.r = *Matrix_at(&img->red_channel, row, column);.   color.g = *Matrix_at(&img->green_channel, row, column);.   color.b = *Matrix_at(&img->blue_channel, row, column);. .   return (Pixel); // not working. }. . // REQUIRES: img points to a valid Image. //           0 <= row && row < Image_height(img). //           0 <= column && column < Image_width(img). // MODIFIES: *img. // EFFECTS:  Sets the pixel in the Image at the given row and column. //           to the given color.. void Image_set_pixel(Image* img, int row, int column, Pixel color) {.   assert(img->width && img->height);.   assert(0 <= row && row < Image_height(img));.   assert(0 <= column && column < Image_width(img));.   .   // Accesses the struct object and sets the pixel to the given color.   // by reading each of the red, green, and blue matrices..   Pixel color = Image_get_pixel(img, row, column);. .   color.r = *Matrix_at(&img->red_channel, row, column);.   color.g = *Matrix_at(&img->green_channel, row, column);.   color.b = *Matrix_at(&img->blue_channel, row, column);. }. Might be easier to read this way..
i_answer: You have the right idea in the Image_get_pixel function as it is supposed to just access the Matrix channels of the image and return the values in a Pixel struct. You just have to return the Pixel object you create and not the general "Pixel" data type.. . For Image_set_pixel, you do not return anything as the goal is to again index into the Matrix channels of the image, and this time set the three matrices at the given row and column with the given pixel. You do not need to call Image_get_pixel in there as you are given the Pixel you are setting the color channels to via the "Pixel color" parameter. Using this parameter, access the color channel matrices at the given row/col and set each one to the corresponding value of the color parameter.

subject: remove_vertical_seam always removing last column
content: My remove_vertical_seam function is only ever removing the last column of an image. Currently, I have it set up as an if function where if the column number < the seam column number, it copies the pixel from img into the smaller image, and if the column number > the seam column number, it copies the pixel over. Is there an obvious problem in my logic? I've tried debugging and it always appears that it's only copying over the correct values but my _removed.out.ppm shows that it is only removing the last column.
i_answer: Splitting the pixel copying action logically between col\seam seems appropriate, but make sure that when it's "copying the pixel over", it puts each input pixel in the output image, but moved to the left by 1---that is, if `seam[2] == 3`, for example, then the input pixel at row 2, column 5 should be written to row 2, column 4 in the output image.

subject: Seam_carve functions
content: Can someone explain how to approach the seam_carve_width, seam_carve_height, and seam_carve functions? I know we have to call all the functions listed on the specs but I'm confused about the creating matrix objects part.
i_answer: For seam_carve_width, I used a while loop in order to keep carving until the width was equal to the newWidth. Outside of the loop, I created two new matrices: the energy and cost matrices. Inside of the loop, I initialized and computed the energy matrix, initialized and computed the cost matrix, then initialized (with max height see @768), found, and removed the seam using each of the functions we previously created in processing. . . For seam_carve_height, I rotated the img to the left, called seam_carve_width, and rotated it back. . . For seam_carve, I called seam_carve_width and then seam_carve_height.

subject: Trouble w/ image_set_pixel
content: I keep getting errors when I index into pixels like this, but why? The objects are pixels so I don't see why there is an issue. How do I fix this and implement the function properly?. imagesetpixel.png
i_answer: First of all, this is a void function. Void functions do not return anything. . In your function, seting red, green, and blue to cred, creen, and crue does nothing because the red, green, and blue variables are never used again.. Also, the Image_get_pixel function returns a pixel, not a *pixel. . . For each image, there are three matrixes: red_channel, green_channel, and blue_channel.. I think to implement this function, you should use the Matrix_at function with the given row and column on each of these matrices and set the value of the matrix to the corresponding r g or b value of the color pixel.

subject: Problem with Image_print
content: . void Image_print(const Image* img, std::ostream& os) {. Pixel test;. Pixel test1;. os << "P3" << std::endl;. os << img->width << " " << img->height << std::endl;. os << "255" << std::endl;. for (int i = 0; i < img->height; ++i){.   for (int j = 0; j < img->width; ++j){.    .  .  . .     os << test.r << " " << test.g << " " << test.b << " ";.     if (i == img->height - 1 && j == img->width - 1){.       os << std::endl;.     }.   }. }. }. . . So this is what we have for our Image_print function (we are trying to match the public test case right now) and we have an idea on how to match the print format needed, but we are struggling with the syntax. The bolded line is the line that is giving us the issue, and is also the line that we are using to print in the proper format. We have looked into modifying lvalues and how it is not possible, but we aren't sure of how to go about writing this in a way that doesn't give us syntax errors. Thank you.

subject: Why is autograder giving me this error?
content: I don't understand why I have this error as there is literally a member variable int width in Image.
i_answer: The error you are receiving here has to do with the fact that you are not respecting the interfaces.. You should not be directly accessing the data held by your image struct using the -> operator in your processing.cpp file. Instead, you should use the functions you wrote to access this data (Image_width, Image_height, Image_get_pixel, etc).. . Please read the "Respect the interfaces!" section of the project spec. . https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#interface-1

subject: A question about the implementation of rotate_left function.
content: This is the given implementation of rotate_left function.. . . In this implementation, a new auxiliary image is created and the new rotated image is stored into it. To my understanding, the memory diagram  should be like, there are two image objects in the dynamic allocated memory. Before copying back, img is pointed to the original image object and aux is pointed to the new rotated image. Therefore, we need to first delete the original image object in the dynamic memory, then let img points to the new rotated image. So to my understanding this implementation should be like this:. . delete img; // delete the original image object in the dynamic memory. img = aux;  //let img points to the new rotated image. But the correct implementation is apparantly not the same as what I thought. Where am I thinking wrong? Thanks so much for answering my doubt!

subject: Remove vertical seam issues
content: Hi, below I have pasted my implementation for remove_vertical_seam. The idea was to iterate through the image, and if the index stored in seam is equal to the current column, take the pixel AFTER the skipped one from the original image and add it to the new one. If the index stored in seam is not equal to the current column, just copy and paste the pixel from the original image. It complies and I do not get any indexing assertion error. I do get an assert failure because the correct image and the one produced by the algorithm are not equal. Any advice on what could be going wrong is greatly appreciated.
i_answer: Let's say your image is 10x10 and in your current row, you want to skip column 4. Let us now say that j == 7. This means we would want to copy col 8 of our old image into col 7 of our new image. In your current code, since 7!=4, would go into the first if statement and copy col 7 of our old image into col 7 of our new image. You may want to look into separating your cases into before the removal col, and after the removal column instead.

subject: Accessing image files created in processing_public_tests

You may find it useful to look at the results from your own code and visually compare them to the provided correct outputs when debugging the algorithm.". . In the spec, it says the line above in the section about processing_public_tests. We are confused how to access the image files created by our functions.
i_answer: After running processing_public_tests.exe, these files are created in your working directory with the extension .out appended before the .ppm extension. The correct files that you should compare these to have the extension .correct appended.

subject: Matrix_At function
content: Why doesn't this work for my matrix_at function?
i_answer: Underneath the hood, a Matrix object is a struct that contains `int width; int height;` and `int data[500]`. In other words, all the data is only in a 1D array. Our goal of this project is in `Matrix.cpp` to make our Matrix look and work as a 2D array with the functions we are implementing. . . In this function, with the information you have (width, height, and a 1D array), how can you get the ptr to the right place in the 1D array given a row and column? If this is confusing, I recommend checking the p2 overview slides on eecs280.org, it gives a visual diagram for what we are trying to do

subject: Starting Late on P2
content: I'm starting super late on the project and I'm worried about not being able to finish in time. Is there any way I can optimize my time?
i_answer: Like the student response mentions, tackle the files in this order: matrix.cpp -> image.cpp -> processing.cpp -> resize.cpp. It’ll be especially helpful in matrix.cpp and processing.cpp to make sure you fully understand what the algorithms want you to compute before jumping straight into the code (I found that having a scrap paper next to me to draw out example matrices was really useful for visualizing things).. . Write test cases for matrix and image if you need a break since those are a little more manual and require less big brain thinking. You got this, good luck!.

subject: how do i fix oclint - Long Lines
content: clint -no-analytics -rule=LongLine -rc=LONG_LINE=90 -max-priority-1 0 -max-priority-2 0 -max-priority-3 0 Matrix.cpp processing.cpp Image.cpp resize.cpp -- -xc++ --std=c++11234OCLint Report56Summary: TotalFiles=4 FilesWithViolations=2 P1=0 P2=0 P3=278/home/autograder/working_dir/Matrix.cpp:203:1: long line [size|P3] Line with 101 characters exceeds limit of 909/home/autograder/working_dir/processing.cpp:93:1: long line [size|P3] Line with 98 characters exceeds limit of 901011[OCLint (http://oclint.org) v0.13]12public.mk:176: recipe for target 'style-oclint-lines' failed
i_answer: Adding to the student answer, you can see which lines need to be shortened by looking after the colon on each file name. For example, `blahblahblah/Matrix.cpp:203:1` means line 203 in `Matrix.cpp` is too long.

subject: Is a matrix with only one row and one column a valid matrix?

subject: requires asserts
content: Confused on how I would check if. cost points to a Matrix and energy and cost aren't pointing to the same Matrix in my asserts?
i_answer: This isn't something you have to explicitly check. The assert statements for the requires clause are optional, but sometimes we don't expect you to check them at all. They're there so you know what is expected and what you should be passing in when using the function.

subject: Do we need to write separate test for edge cases?
i_answer: Yes, you should think of some edge cases for the functions you implemented and write some test cases to check those edge cases.

subject: oclint long functon errors for resize.cpp
content: This is the full error message:. . ```. /home/autograder/working_dir/resize.cpp:12:1: high ncss method [size|P2] Method of 52 non-commenting source statements exceeds limit of 40. ```. . Line 12 in my resize.cpp is the declaration of the `main` function. I currently have my function defined like this:. ```cpp. int main(int argc, char* argv[]) {}. ```. How should I resolve this error if the function is meant to take in a command line input?
i_answer: Are there any parts of your main function that could be put into its own function? For instance, if there are 60 lines in your main and you copy-paste 30 of them into a different function, then you can just make the call in main to the other function you just created and save some lines. Remember that the style checker just checks to see that every function has less than 40 lines, it doesn't care about how many functions you make.

subject: Matrix_at() for testing or use streams?

subject: Do we need to test Matrix_fill again if there's already the TEST(test_fill_basic)?

subject: Processing.cpp - issue with remove vertical seam
content: Our project is failing dog_seam_carve after passing the find seam and remove vertical seam test and our carved image is only slightly different from the correct one, which would make it seem like an off by one error perhaps but we have spent a lot of time debugging it and cannot find anything, everything seems to copy over fine from the image to the smaller image then we use pointers to copy the smaller image to the original image. Here is our code, we're pretty sure the issue is in remove vertical seam, but pretty stuck, could be something big we're doing wrong as well, who knows. Also posted question @1098 which has more information on our test output
i_answer: It looks like the error is originating in your compute_energy_matrix function. Based on the spec, we know that the border must always be 0. Looking at your code on the autograder, we have some undefined behavior. On the first iteration of the for loop, r = 0 and c = 0 so it will fail the first if statement. The computer will then go to the second if statement (Energy > maxEnergy. At this point, energy hasn't been initialized to a value, resulting in undefined behavior. I would suggest creating a better way to fill the border with 0's.. . Hope this helps!

subject: Image_init errors
content: I'm pretty stuck on my second Image_init function, and I don't know how to resolve the errors I have. i_answer: It looks like you are trying to reference img->height[num] and img->width[num]. This is throwing an error because height and width is just an integer. The [] only work on arrays and vectors. You can find more information on img and it's attributes in the Image.h file.. . Hope this helps!

subject: Compue_energy_matrix problems
content: Hi, I am trying to implement what I have written so far in the compute_energy_matrix function by running it through the processing public tests. subject: Testing matrix_at while respecting interface
content: How do I test matrix_at without using mat->data? I'm using pointer arithmetic to get the address of the first value in the matrix array and then adding it by a value. I'm then comparing this address with Matrix_at.. Edit: I apologize. I see that this was addressed in Project 2 FAQ.
i_answer: marking as resolved

subject: Matrix false positive test cases
content: My test functions for matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row and matrix_min_value_in_row are both getting detected as false positives and I'm not sure why. I've checked my test cases multiple times and I'm not sure why they're false positives.
i_answer: From pulling up your autograder solution, here's your matrix:. [1, 2, 3]. [3, 16, 9]. [5, 11, 4]. [6, 13, 17]. [7, 12, 2]. . For your first assertion:. ASSERT_EQUAL(Matrix_min_value_in_row(mat, 1, 1, 2), 9);. This looks for the min value in row 1 between column 1 (inclusive) & column 2 (exclusive). Really, we are just returning whatever is in row 1, column 1, so we would expect the value to be 16, not 9.. . I would pay attention to the RME for Matrix_min_value_in_row and Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row since column end is exclusive, and update your implementation accordingly! .

subject: Overwriting values in a Matrix with Matrix_at

subject: matrix_init in img
content: I'm trying to initialize a Matrix in the img_init function but for some reason my parameter for the *mat isn't matching up- in the first parameter for the matrix_init function is it not just img?
i_answer: If you look at the image struct in Image.h, there are 3 different matrices for each image representing each of the red, green, and blue color channels. In the Image_init function, you must initialize each of these three matrices using the Matrix_init function. You can access the channel matrices using the -> operator on the image. Don't forget the Matrix_init function takes an address as the first parameter.

subject: Mutation Testing Suites Error
content: Hi, in my mutation testing suites, I have some test functions that say they give false positives and some that are valid; however they are for the same function and are implemented the same. Is there any explanation for that?
i_answer: If you're saying that two tests are exactly the same but one gives a false positive, I think that this is impossible. I would recommend running through with your debugger to see if the inputs to your test are any different. . . If you're saying that there are two tests testing the same function but one is giving a false positive, then that means your asserts in one test is incorrect, or in other words your asserts are invalid when tested against a correct implementation. . . An example of a false positive: . vec = {10,20,30}. ASSERT_TRUE(sum(vec) == 3); // this is not valid, the answer should be 60

subject: Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row pointer
content: . For this code, I have a problem where I use '&' to take the address of the starting value and values to replace it. It gives there error 'a value of 'const int *' cannot be used to initialize an entity of type 'int *'. I believe we covered something like this in lecture, but I'm still confused.. . int Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row(const Matrix* mat, int row,. int column_start, int column_end) {. assert((0 <= row) && (row < Matrix_height(mat)));. assert((0 <= column_start) && (column_end < Matrix_width(mat)));. assert(column_start < column_end);. . int min = mat->data[(row*(mat->width))+column_start];. int* ptr = &(mat->data[(row*(mat->width))+column_start]);. . for (int i = (row*(mat->width))+column_start; i < (row*(mat->width))+column_end; i++). {. if (mat->data[i] < min). {. min = mat->data[i];. ptr = &(mat->data[i]);. }. . }.
i_answer: There is a type mismatch on the line you pointed out: int* ptr = &(mat->data[(row*(mat->width))+column_start]);. . This is because the definition on the left is of type int* and the expression on the right evaluates to a const int*. You could change the definition to be a const int*, but then you may run into issues with changing this const value.. . You can, and should, use the other functions in Matrix.cpp to access the pointers and traverse for the Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row function. This will take care of the arithmetic and pointer accesses you are attempting in this code snippet, and should greatly simplify the implementation.

subject: problem with Matrix row function
content: I wrote a test case for my Matrix row function, but the test keeps failing and I am not sure why.. . . int Matrix_row(const Matrix* mat, const int* ptr) {. int width = mat -> width;. int height = mat -> height;. . for(int row = 0; row < height; row++) {. for(int col = 0; col < width; col++) {. if(ptr == Matrix_at(mat, row, col)) {. return row;. }. }. }. return 0;. }. . . . . TEST(test_row_col) {. Matrix *mat = new Matrix;. Matrix_init(mat, 3, 3);. int value = 6;. const int *ptr = &value;. . Matrix_fill(mat, 0);. *Matrix_at(mat, 2, 2) = 6;. . ASSERT_EQUAL(Matrix_row(mat, ptr), 2);. ASSERT_EQUAL(Matrix_column(mat, ptr), 2);. . delete mat;. }. . . . output: 0 != 2
i_answer: `ptr` is pointing to `value`, not pointing to any element in the matrix, that's why `Matrix_row` will always return zero.

subject: what functions do we want to call in main?
content: i made if statements for the errors but what am i supposed to do after thta?
i_answer: Assuming you are referencing the main in resize.cpp:. . you want to input the contents of the file (using ifstream) specified by the command line argument into a new image (and initialize it using the width and height at the start of the file) and then call your seam carving function on this image using the width/height specified by the command line arguments. You then want to use your Image_print function to output the resized image to a file (using ofstream) with the filename specified by the command line argument. Don't forget to delete the image you created to avoid memory leaks.

subject: processing_public_test horses
content: processing_public_tests passes for all dog and crabster tests but when it tries to run horse it times out. I'm pretty sure the issue is my algorithm for compute_vertical_cost_matrix is doing overlapping calculations but I didn't understand the specs explanation for how to avoid that
i_answer: Could you clarify what you don't understand about these instructions?. . 1. Initialize the cost matrix. . 2. Fill in the index 0 row with its energy values (It is the first row so there are no previous energy values to add to the cost). . 3. Loop through the matrix starting from row index 1, the cost for each pixel is the min value of the adjacent columns of the cost row that you filled in the previous iteration + the energy of the pixel itself. You can find this using the Matrix_min_value_in_row on the previous row of the cost matrix and adding that to the Matrix_at of the current pixel in the energy matrix.

Matrix_public_test.exe: Matrix.cpp:89: int* Matrix_at(Matrix*, int, int): Assertion `0 <= column && column < Matrix_width(mat)' failed.Aborted (core dumped). . and we are not sure why.. . . . int* Matrix_at(Matrix* mat, int row, int column) {. . .   assert(0 <= row && row < Matrix_height(mat));.   assert(0 <= column && column < Matrix_width(mat));. .   int index = mat->width*row;.   int* ptr1 = &mat->data[index];.   int* element_ptr = ptr1 + column;.   return element_ptr;. }. . . This is what our Matrix_at function looks like, but the public test makes it seem like we are going out of the bounds we set for the function with assert(). Any assistance would be greatly appreciated, thank you.

subject: void Image_set_pixel(Image* img, int row, int column, Pixel color) {
content: why cant i say. . *Matrix_at(&img->blue_channel, row, column) = color->b ?. the color->b underline as incorrect but works when i do color.b. why?. .
i_answer: -> is the same as "dereferencing" or getting the actual object associated with a pointer and then using `.` , for example `img->blue_channel` is equivalent to `(*img).blue_channel`. . `Pixel color` is a struct object, not a pointer to an object. So you want to access the attribute in the struct with a `.` , there is nothing to dereference

subject: compute_vertical_cost_matrix indexing
content: i understand that we fill in the first row with just the energy values as the cost because there are no values above it.. however, in the second row and onwards i'm a little confused on how to get the cost for the first and last columns (beginning and end of the row). do i have to create separate for loops for these columns since the algorithm given in the specs:. . [cost(r, c) = energy(r, c) + min(cost(r-1, c-1), cost(r-1, c), cost(r-1, c+1))]. . will return an out of bounds error when I call (r-1, c-1) and (r-1,c+1)?. . thank you
i_answer: You don't need separate for loops, you can write an if-then statement.

subject: Completely lost on broken assert
content: One of my asserts keeps failing - a simple one, which is:. . assert(column >= 0 && column < Matrix_width(mat));. Everything, every line of code I have in place makes sure that column does not go over Matrix_width.. In compute_energy_matrix, I use matrix_init, setting the width and height to the image's width and height.. I do not loop past the bounds of the matrix's dimensions, which are identical to the image's dimensions. The column is always >= 0 and always less than the Matrix width. And yet, the assert fails.. . . How? I don't understand at all, when I remove the assert and run the code it outputs exactly the correct response. But when I put it back in, it should not fail but it does. The row assert that does the exact same thing works just fine. Any ideas?
i_answer: As the student suggests, the debugger is your best resource in a situation like this. It will help you trace through the functions called to get you to your current state, and show you the local variable values along the way. If you are still stuck, consider visiting office hours to get some help stepping through it with a member of the course staff.

Next, prints out the rows of the image, each followed by a. //           newline. Each pixel in a row is printed as three ints. //           for its red, green, and blue components, in that order. ". . we are trying to use img->red_channel and other matrices to get the info in each pixel and print them out right???
i_answer: To my understanding, the image_print function just needs to print the info using some sort of output stream, so in my function I just used os << "whatever I want to print out" and this still means the function is void.. Also to your second question, yes. I think I read in some other post that the statement "&img->red_channel" will be used frequently in order to access the RGB values at that pixel.

subject: red, green, blue channel
content: What the red_channel, green channel, and blue channel contain? I know the they are matrix. What is their matrix about? For example, in row 0 and col 0, red pixel is 0, so row 0 and col 0 in red channel is also 0? Sorry I am confused about these three new matrices.
i_answer: Essentially the red,green, and blue channels are just matrices that are storing the RGB values at each pixel but in separate matrices. For example if I have a 2x2 image, the pixel at row = 0, column = 0 will have one set of RGB values.. The first value in my red_channel will be the R value for that pixel also at row = 0, column = 0. The same applies to the blue and green channels. Also let's say I wanted to access my RGB values at some random pixel in the image, then. I would use my Matrix_at function (because red_channel is a matrix) with the statement "&img->red_channel" to access that R value. . . Basically, each color_channel is another matrix that has the corresponding color values at the same row and column as your image.. . Hope this is right and helps

subject: Testing processing.cpp
content: Hello,. I was wondering if anyone knows a good strategy for how to write tests for processing.cpp since the correct energy and cost matrices take a long time to calculate. Also, if we write tests for processing.cpp in a copy of processing_public_tests.cpp, how should we compile the file? Should we add a command to the Makefile?
i_answer: When testing processing.cpp, I would suggest writing smaller test cases of computing the energy and cost matrix so that it does not take as long to calculate. Smaller test cases (maybe a 7 by 7 ish size) are something you can generate a correct output for. Make sure that these test cases are targeted though! Think about all the bounds and if statements in your function. The test case should attempt to run every single line and if condition in the function.. . Hope this helps!

Assertion failed: (column < Matrix_width(mat)), function Matrix_at, file Matrix.cpp, line 119.. Abort trap: 6. . Thank you so much for your time!

subject: min
content: If a row of elements have two numbers that both are a minimum, what do we do??. For example, if a row involved [1,2,3,2,1], which column would be considered the min value? The 0th or the 4th?
i_answer: It is included in the RME.. ```. If multiple elements are minimal, returns the column of the leftmost one.. ```

subject: Can we assess Matrix's members in test file?
content: When we are writing test, let's say that we have initialized a matrix:. . . Matrix *mat = new Matrix;. const int width = 3;. const int height = 5;. Matrix_init(mat, 3, 5);. . . Are we allowed to use mat->width to test if the data in mat is correctly? Is this "respect the interface"?
i_answer: You may not use any of the Matrix struct's data members (width, height or data[]) outside the matrix file. none of the other files, including test files should access Matrix data members. As you rightly pointed out, this would violate the "Respect the Interface" guideline for this project.
