subject: Address santinizer setup
content: I'm using VScode, and I'm curious about why I need to both add compiler flags to my MakeFile and configure the environment parameter in the launch.json when configuing address santinizer.. To my understanding, if I want to use VScode to debug, I firstly need to compile it in the command line, then click the run and debug button in VScode, and if there is something wrong, I will be notified during the compiling phase. So why I still need to enable the address sanitizer by editing my launch.json? How does it work?. Thanks for answering my doubts!
i_answer: By adding compiler flags in your make file, if there is undefined behavior, the program aborts and shows you the error trace. However, you may need to take a lot of time thinking about what went wrong since the error output could be massive. By configuring the environment parameter in `launch.json` allows the debugger to abort and show you the line that causes the undefined behavior. That's much more useful in debugging.

subject: find_minimal_vertical_seam()

content: Hi.. In the autograder under Resize public tests its giving me a score of 1/1 but saying I failed showing:. . . Exit status: x. . . Actual exit status: 1. . . Expected exit status: 0. . subject: Test cases

subject: What does it mean to copy an image?
content: Right now, my code creates an image pointer (Image* aux = new Image) and initializes it according to the project spec. Then in the last line, I am setting img = aux so that it points to aux, but I wonder if it no longer points to aux when the function ends bc aux will be out of scope?. .
i_answer: Nice to hear that you have solved this.. . Think of this `*img = *aux` as copying the "content" of aux to img, because when you dereferencing the pointer, you will get the actual struct that is pointed by the vector. When you do `*img = *aux`, you will replace the original struct with the struct that is pointed by aux.

subject: using min value row "backwards"
content: For the min value function (not the column one), can we use it backwards? For example, can we have column_start be towards the right side of the matrix and column_end be towards the left side and read the range of values from right to left instead of the traditional left to right?. . Thank you in advance.
i_answer: Your min_value_in_row function should do what the RME specifies; specifically, column_start needs to be the left boundary, and column_end needs to be one past the right boundary. You can read from right to left or left to right within the function.

subject: seam[height] compilation warning in Processing.cpp
content: We are receiving a compilation warning in autograder for our processing.cpp in our seam_carve_width function. It says C++ forbids variable length array 'seam' in int seam[height]... where we wrote int height = Image_height(img) on the line above. We understand that arrays are not allowed to vary in length. But we don't know how to maneuver this compilation warning with the purpose of the function.
i_answer: Seam doesn't necessarily need to equal the height. It simply needs to be at least as long as the height. This is similar to how data in Matrix is the maximum possible length required—not the exact length needed for a specific height and width. With that in mind, consider using a constant variable (that we were given in a .h file) to set seam to be a length which is always greater than or equal to height.

subject: remove_vertical_seam() confusion
content: I read on an earlier post that I should point the pointer that points to the original image matrix over to the copy matrix, but I don't know how that would work since we delete the copy at the end. It works on the debugger until the debugger exits out of the function, then the original image loses the dimensions of the copy and has its old dimensions again. Would anyone be able to help me with this?
i_answer: The phrasing in your post "point the pointer that points to the original image matrix over to the copy matrix" is a bit misleading, as you are correct in that the final image has to be deleted through that same pointer. Instead, think about it as copying the data inside the pointer from the auxiliary image to the original image.

subject: What are Mutation Testing Suites and how are they graded
content: Where should I start for the "exposed bugs"?
i_answer: A mutation test suite is a set of unit tests that are run against buggy implementations of code. You get points based on if your test case reveals those bugs (for example, if your test case is run against an incorrect Matrix_fill function, you will get a point if your test case fails, which means it found that bug). You can write test cases as normal just like you did in p1; be sure to think about different edge cases for your Matrix and Image functions!. . @921 includes a helpful explanation as well.

subject: Image
content: Just like Matrix, do we also have to think of Image as a 1D array?
i_answer: No, the only abstraction was that the Matrix in real implementation was a 1D array. Outside of the implementation, Matrix is supposed to look and be used like a 2D array. Because Image is using Matrix, you only have to see the abstraction and not the implementation, so you can think of the three red, green, blue matrices as a 2D arrays from the outside.

subject: Compute_vertical_cost_matrix()
content: Hello,. . I was debugging my code, and when I went to my compute_vertical_cost_matrix function, I realized that I was violating the requires clause of the matrix_min_value_in_row() when I was doing the edge case for when calculating the matrix pixel on the last column. . . What I currently have is Matrix_min_value_in_row(cost, row - 1, col, col + 2), but when I do col + 2, it goes out of bounds. The only reason I am doing col + 2 is because the RME for matrix_min_value_in_row says that the function is exclusive on the column end part. . . Any help would be appreciated :)
i_answer: I think I found the problem here. Even when the function is exclusive on the last column, you don't need to do col + 2, just do col + 1 instead. This way, if your for loop has (index < col_end), it will never actually try to index out of bounds. Right now, with your code, it indexes at data[col + 1], which is not possible. So I think changing the +2 to a +1 would fix the problem. . .

subject: Confusion with Matrix_at and const Matrix_at
content: I am not sure how I can test if const Matrix_at is working. I tried setting up the constant pointer, filled the indices into a single value, and modified one of the indices; but when I stepped through the debugger, the Matrix_at function on the second line gets called to the non-const version. . . Also, I'm not sure the difference between dereferencing the constant pointer and the Matrix_at function and why would they return different results?. . . I would really appreciate any suggestions of how I can test this function.
i_answer: I changed this post to private - please don't include any code in a public post. . . Did you declare mat as a pointer to const as well? If mat is not a pointer to a const matrix, then the other Matrix_at will be called, which I believe is what is happening in this situation. To test the matrix_at that takes a pointer-to-const, you need to send it a pointer to a const matrix in the parameters. . . You get an error when you try to dereference stay because stay is declared as a pointer to const, and you're not supposed to be able to alter the value that it points to. You don't get an error at the dereference to matrix_at because, like you pointed out in your post, I believe you're calling the non-const Matrix_at.

subject: Calling Matrix functions inside Image.cpp

i_answer: You will want to call the functions in Matrix.cpp in Image.cpp. In order to "respect the interface", you should not directly access members of the Matrix struct in Image.cpp (mat->height, mat->width, mat->data).

subject: Testing Image_Init
content: My partner and I are trying to test Image_Init by passing in a ppm file given to us in the project. We want to use ifstream for this but cant figure out a way that the syntax works.
i_answer:
You cannot submit extraneous txt files to the autograder, so you cannot use `fstream` for your Image tests. Instead, you have to use stringstreams for these kinds of tests. You can think of a stringstream as "acting" like standard input/output or file input/output, but instead of the source being the command line or a file, it's a string.. . For example, if you want to simulate reading in a file like this:. ```. P3. 1 1. 255. 42. ```. You can declare a string with that content, initialize an input string stream (an `istringstream`) with that string as the content, and then read it in like a file or standard input.. ```. string s = "P3
1 1
255
42";. istringstream ss(s);. string junk;. ss >> junk >> .... ```. For testing output, you'd do the opposite order. Output to a string stream, then convert the output to a string and compare it with a "test" string if you want to use `ASSERT_EQUAL` in your tests. . ```. ostringstream ss;. ss << "Outputing to stream";. string s = ss.str();. ```

subject: Does autograder give feedback for invalid tests immediately after I submit, or after the deadline?
content: Hi, as the title, does the Autograder give out feedback for valid/invalid unit tests immediately after I submit, or after the deadline?. Say, I wrote several tests but failed to catch a certain bug, will the autograder let me know immediately? And would the autograder let me know what is the input?
i_answer: The AG will only tell you how many bugs you're catching, and how many points out of the maximum possible number of points you're getting for your test cases. This output is visible after submitting your test cases, and test case scores are final (meaning the score you see on the AG is the score you will receive for test cases, even after private tests are run)

subject: resize.cpp Memory leak
content: Hello,. I have been testing my resize.cpp function to see what it would do if I gave it an invalid input. My file did crash and return the proper error message when I used an invalid input, but it also detected a memory leak because I needed to declare a new *img before I could check its width/height. Since my program exited before deleting the *img, it causes a memory leak. Is there a way to change my code to avoid this memory leak or is it important? I could put delete img in the if statement checking for the invalid input, but I check for multiple errors throughout my code so I was wondering if there was a better way to avoid a memory leak..
i_answer: You should reorganize the code to avoid any memory leaks. This can come in the form of deleting your img on every return, or only creating the img after you check error conditions. How you go about it is up to you, but there should be no memory leaks present in your code.

subject: P2 spec clarification on Matrix loops
content: On the Matrix module part of the specs, it says this:. . "Your Matrix_at functions will need to perform the appropriate arithmetic to convert from a (row, column) pair to an index in the array, and your Matrix_row and Matrix_column functions will need to go in the other direction. None of these functions require a loop, and you’ll find your implementation will be very slow if you use a loop.". . does it mean that only Matrix_at, Matrix_row and Matrix_column don't require a loop or is it talking about all functions in the Matrix module?.
i_answer: It only means that those three functions mentioned (Matrix_at, Matrix_row, Matrix_column) shouldn't be completed using loops. You will have to use loops to implement some other functions in Matrix.cpp

subject: Some confusion about matrix.cpp
content: Hi i have some questions about these functions in matrix.cpp. My questions are in the comments.. I don't know why I can't have two pictures here at the same time, so i can only put rest of my questions here:. . Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row:. . So first, we have multiple rows in 2d array, do we still go through the 1d array finding the least element, then get it's column index in 2d array??? Is this the right idea???. .
i_answer: Matrix_fill: . You are given a value as a parameter to the function, you want to fill the entire matrix with this value. . . You are given mat, which is a pointer to a Matrix object. Matrix has 3 attributes: data, width, height. You need to specify which data attribute you want to access. This is usually done with the dot operator, but since mat is a pointer you need to dereference it first. For example, to access data you would want something like (*mat).data or mat->data. . . Matrix_fill_border: . @841 - the followups explains why we want to have fill_border vs. just fill . . Matrix_max:. Wants you to return the value of the maximum element in the data array of the Matrix object that mat points to.

subject: False Positives
content: Hi, when I put my Matrix_tests.cpp and Matrix.cpp files into the autograder, it says I have false positives in a couple of my tests. I'm a bit confused on how I go about fixing those? What is a false positive too?
i_answer: A false positive means that your test case failed on a working example. So when we ran your test cases against our correct solutions, some of them reported a bug when they shouldn't have. This could indicate that you have an incorrect understanding of how some functions should behave based on certain inputs.

subject: About Matrix_at
content: Hi i have a problem about how to implement matrix_at, I know how to calculate the 1d array index with 2d array index(i.e row and column and width and height), but that will give me the index of that object in 1d array instead of its address, which is a pointer, how can i get the pointer pointing to that object with the index i calculated?. .  *ptr = row * (mat->width) + column; I use this expression but i don't think this is correct, cuz when i dereference pointer it gives me a address, but essentially row * (mat->width) + column give me an index, which is super weird. I am quite unfamiler with c++ syntax, please help!!!. .
i_answer: row, mat->width, and column are all numbers, so any calculation with them will give you a number, which we can think of as an index. When declaring pointers, we need to set them to the address of objects, not the object's value. . . With that being said, if you've figured out how to calculate the index of an element, then you've already accomplished most of this function. An index is essentially how many elements away you are from the beginning of an array. We also know that arrays are represented as pointers to their first element. We can translate the index of an element into the address of an element using pointer arithmetic.

subject: what is red_channel, green channel, blue channel
content: I know how the PPM and image formed, but I don't know what the red_channel, green channel, and blue channel use for.
i_answer: red channel, green channel, blue channel represent the colors that form the image. From red, green, and blue you can form almost all colors so these are used (in combination with each other) to form colors on a screen. In the project your input is given by the values of these three channels (which is why your image struct stores all of them), you then do consistent operations on these channels in order to do seam carving and the other stuff listed in the spec. You need to change all these values (on all the channels) so the output is viewable on a computer in the form of an image.

subject: Compute_energy_matrix
content: I know that we have to call 'square_difference' in Compute_energy_matrix, however, the parameters for that function are pixels. How do we know the exact pixels that we need to pass in? Also, can someone explain how we find N,S,E,W when we don't know where exactly we are in the image.. . THANK YOU.
i_answer: To calculate the energy for each non-border pixel X, we use the formula `energy(X) = squared\_difference(N, S) + squared\_difference(W, E)`. . The values for N, S, E, and W are simply the adjacent pixels. This is why we only use this method to calculate the energy for non-border pixels. So north is simply `row_of_x - 1`, east is `column_of_x + 1`, etc. In a double for loop, you can use those offsets from the current pixel being calculated.. . You can also see the explanation in the [p2 spec](https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#energy-matrix).

subject: Help with understanding Image_set_pixel
content: Right now, I'm currently at a complete halt with project because I'm having a hard time understanding how Image_get_pixel works and to even get it working. The part I don't understand is how does it set it to that color and how does VS code read it as a color?
i_answer: `Image_get_pixel()` shouldn’t change any values in the `Image`. That’s what `Image_set_pixel()` is for. If you look in `Image.h`, you’ll see that the return type of `Image_get_pixel()` is `Pixel`. Your code needs to create a `Pixel` (you don’t need to use new), set its values to the corresponding values in the red, green, and blue matrices, and then return that `Pixel`.. . To answer the second part of your question, reading color values is super simple because each one is just an `int`. VS Code doesn't need to do anything special.

subject: Interface

i_answer: See @881. An interface is basically the functions you will interact with to read or change an object. For example, `Matrix_at` is part of the interface for interacting with `Matrix` functions.

subject: out of bounds RME
content: Hi!. . If the rows and columns are 0-indexed, then how can column_end be equal to Matrix_width(mat)? Wouldn't that be out of bounds?. . . . Thanks!
i_answer: The range of columns excludes `column_end` (since it says "exclusive" in EFFECTS). So if the matrix width is 5 and you have `column_start = 2` and `column_end = 5`, it will look for the minimum value in the specified row in columns 2, 3, and 4 (thus excluding 5).

subject: Confused on how to test Image_init with streams
content: I wrote a test function for Image_init with streams.. I used one of the ppm starter files and printed the output of image_init to a separate txt file.. I was confused on how I could compare the original ppm and the new output txt file and check for differences. I'm also curious on how autograder will try check tests I wrote for image_init.
i_answer:
You cannot submit extraneous txt files to the autograder. Instead, you have to use stringstreams for these kinds of tests. You can think of a stringstream as "acting" like standard input/output or file input/output, but instead of the source being the command line or a file, it's a string.. . For example, if you want to simulate reading in a file like this:. ```. P3. 1 1. 255. 42. ```. You can declare a string with that content, initialize an input string stream (an `istringstream`) with that string as the content, and then read it in like a file or standard input.. ```. string s = "P3
1 1
255
42";. istringstream ss(s);. string junk;. ss >> junk >> .... ```. For testing output, you'd do the opposite order. Output to a string stream, then convert the output to a string and compare it with a "test" string if you want to use `ASSERT_EQUAL` in your tests. . ```. ostringstream ss;. ss << "Outputing to stream";. string s = ss.str();. ```

subject: shorter way of implementing remove_vertical_seam()?
content: Hi,. . For the function remove_vertical_seam(), the RME hints that you should create a smaller image and later delete it. My function works when implemented this way. However, I believe an alternative way to implement this function would be to modify the original matrix: leave the elements before the column to be removed as is, move the elements beyond that one to the left each, then call Matrix_init() and reduce the height and width of the matrix by 1 each. This would run faster due to fewer loops.. . Is the efficiency here that important? Which method would you recommend?
i_answer: We recommend the first way. `Matrix_init` is meant to be called exactly once to initialize a matrix, and doing the second method would break that desired interface. By using the first method, the efficiency won't change enough for the autograder to complain.

i_answer: You will want to make sure you include Image.h

subject: Creating new objects through pointers
content: For a lot of new object instantiations, I see the examples using pointers like so:. .     Matrix* m = new Matrix;.     Matrix_init(m, 20, 20);. . . Can someone remind me what the difference would be if I instead had. . . .     Matrix m = new Matrix;.     Matrix_init(m, 20, 20);. . . where m is no longer a pointer but is the Matrix itself?
i_answer: The "new" operator returns a pointer to the newly-created object, so something like "Matrix m = new Matrix;" won't compile due to a type mismatch.. The reason why "new" returns a pointer is because it allocates the new object on the heap, which is typically far away in memory from where the current function's activation record on the stack is. Thus, we need a pointer to that location  on the heap so we can access and modify the object. Don't worry if this doesn't make too much sense yet -- we'll spend a lot of time talking about dynamic allocation later on in lecture!. Quick fun fact: It is possible for the "new" operator to not return a pointer. If the operating system fails to allocate memory for the object at runtime, the "new" operator throws an exception instead. The chance of you encountering this in 280 is exceedingly low. :)

subject: Seam Size
content: In the find_minimal_vertical_seam function one of the requires statements says "the size of seam is >= Matrix_height(cost)." Is there a way to assert this? I am not sure how to get the length/size of the seam. I tried "seam.size()" but this does not work since seam is of type int*.
i_answer: Since seam is a normal array and not a vector, we don't know its size unless it's explicitly passed into the function as a separate parameter, unfortunately. So while you cannot assert this requirement in find_minimal_vertical_seam(), you can make some logical guarantee in the caller function. That is, since you're writing the caller function, you can make sure to initialize seam to be sufficiently large before passing it in. Hope this helps!

subject: Remove_vertical_seam()
content: How are we supposed to change img's width value in remove_vertical_seam()?. . I followed the instructions, copying everything but the seam of img into a smaller image and then copying the smaller image's contents back into the original image, but when I run processing_public_tests(), it detects that the widths don't match and fails despite the rest of the images being identical. . . When I directly decrement img's width (which I know doesn't respect the interfaces), the function works. Is there another way to do this? The project description seemed to forbid changing the width all together, so I am unsure of what to do.. . Thank you..
i_answer: The smaller image that you create has the correct width and height, instead of copying everything back into the original image, is it possible to somehow set the original image to be the newer smaller image? Consider that you are given a pointer to the original image.

subject: for const int* Matrix_at(const Matrix* mat, int row, int column) {
content: for. . const int* Matrix_at(const Matrix* mat, int row, int column) { can we add the resize to &mat->data or should we put it in the brackets of [] of data still using & in front of mat->data[resize]?. .
i_answer: I'm not sure I understand your question. For this function, mat is a pointer-to-const. This means we're not allowed to change any values of the matrix object that mat points at. You want to consider how you can use pointer arithmetic to get to the correct element in data.

subject: what do we do about the whitespace character in image_init
i_answer: the stream we are passing into image_init() doesn't read whitespace, so you can basically ignore the whitespace character

subject: image->width
content: Just a quick question, the function image_width appears below the function image_print, and we're supposed to get the width of the image in image_print, but I remember not being able to directly get the width because it was bad practice.. should I change the order of the functions and try to use the width function at all times?
i_answer: It's ok to directly access an Image's width in Image.cpp since we are still within the Image module. The getter for Image should be utilized in non-Image files to respect the interface. See this section of the spec for more explanation.

Based on your most recent autograder submission, I'd suggest checking how you assign the r,g,b values to their respective channels and use your debugger to see where the error occurs.

subject: matrix_init
content: 1. After declare the array a[][], should I let mat point to a instead of point to mat?. 2. Do I got empty matrix from this function or a matrix filled with data from mat? Do I fill with data in mat row by row?. 3. I use mat = a; I think it's assign mat point to the first element in a, why it doesn't work?. 4. I define a pointer point to a, but I can't let mat point to that pointer neither. there's an error when mat=ptr(array), what is the type of mat? I can't neither assign int* and int**
i_answer: If you are talking about the matrix_init function in matrix.ccp, all you have to do is access the members of the mat struct and change them to the width and height you are passing into the function. . . If you look at matrix.h file, you will see the matrix struct and its members. Your matrix_init function is passing in a matrix struct called mat. To access its members you do the following:. "matrix struct name"->"member name" . . Then you can set the corresponding struct members to the width and height you are passing in.

subject: Significance of std::endl stream flush vs '\n'?
content: I know that when you insert std::endl in a stream, it "flushes" the stream. Is this fact relevant to us when working with various types of streams for P2?Is only using newline characters (for Matrix_print() output for example) going to cause any memory issues? Just curious. Thanks!
i_answer: Using either should not make a difference.

subject: unfilled matrix
content: if you create a matrix with 2 rows and 2 columns, do you have to fill the spots with actual numbers for it to be considered a valid matrix?
i_answer: I don't know that you have to fill the values in the Matrix with numerical values, but there isn't much of a good reason for not filling the matrix with values. In the best case scenario, you can run your functions without an exception being thrown, but they might give you logical bugs like the max function outputting a number higher than any other number you used. In the worst case (and most likely), the compiler or runtime will give you an error when trying to run a function with that Matrix.

subject: Matrix not deleting
content: While making test cases for my matrix, I realized that even after I deleted the matrix I used from a previous test through "delete mat;", when I initialized a new matrix on a different test without setting its starting values, I got random values which seemed to have bled over from the original matrix's remains in the memory. I could just fill it up using Matrix_fill() right after it's initialized, but is this expected behavior?
i_answer: When you create the new matrix, until you fill it with specific values, it'll put random values inside there. In this case, the values matched your previous Matrix, but this is random and will not always be the case!

subject: Question of find_minimal_vertical_seam
content: I am quite confused about what do we need to do in this function. From the graph, does that mean we need to find the min cost among every number of each row or we just need to find the min cost among the number in blue brackets of each row..
i_answer: you want to find minimum cost among the 3 boxes (when they exist) above your current location as shown in the image captioned "then find the minimum cost pixel above". keep in mind edge cases such as when you're currently on the first or last column (don't want to try and access a column that doesn't exist)

subject: iterate through matrix - matrix_fill
content: I feel like im overcomplicating iterating through this matrix, but you would do a double for loop but then how would you assign the values this is what I have so far but I get the error "Type 'Matrix' does not provide a subscript operator" . I just realized data gets stored in a 1D array lol nvmid so when i assign to interface do i just assign value to all elements of data?. . . void Matrix_fill(Matrix* mat, int value) {.     for(int i = 0; i < mat->width; i++) {.         for (int j; j < mat->height; j++) {.             mat[i][j] = value;.         }.     }.     . }
i_answer: Important thing here is that mat is a pointer to a Matrix object. A matrix object has 3 attributes: width, height, and data. Therefore you need to specify which attribute of your Matrix you're trying to alter. For example, if you want to modify data you would want to do something like (*mat).data or mat->data to get to your data array. . . Since data is a 1D array, you can then loop through and set every element in data.

subject: Assert for valid Matrix
content: I'm adding asserts into the implementations to make sure the inputs match the requirements, but for checking if a matrix is valid or not, how should I go about writing the assert?
i_answer: I think that in class or on the spec somewhere they mentioned that you don't have to check this, since it wouldn't be practical or simple to check this, if even possible.

subject: Getting a SIGABRT Warning
content: I'm getting SIGABRT when I'm running my debugger for the cost matrix function for the crabster.ppm file. I passed all the tests for dog.ppm, does anyone know why it isn't working for crabster.ppm? (ss is from public test file) Anyone know what SIGABRT is too?
i_answer: SIGABRT in this instance means that the assert statement failed. Since assert's goal is effectively to say "This statement must be true", it will stop the program if it isn't. When the statement is false, assert will send a signal to abort the program's execution.. . It's effectively telling you that the two matrices are not equal, in this instance.

subject: Calling Matrix_at in other Matrix.cpp functions
content: When I try to call Matrix_at in other Matrix.cpp functions, like Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row it is automatically calling the const Matrix_at function, which then is causing XCode to give me a bunch of errors. How do I get it so it calls the first Matrix_at function, so I can use it to initialize variables of type int without XCode giving me an error?. . Edit: It may not actually be calling the const version, but it is giving me errors like "Cannot initialize a variable of type 'int' with an rvalue of type 'const int *'" and "Comparison between pointer and integer ('const int *' and 'int')". . Another edit: I think I figured it out! I was trying to assign the address itself to an int variable, rather than the value of the element that the pointer was pointing to. Had to dereference it using *. Haven't tested it yet but the errors went away!
i_answer: marking as resolved - glad you figured it out!

subject: const Matrix_at
content: I seem to be having a lot of trouble with const Matrix_at. I have been trying to initially create a pointer and initialize it to mat->data. However, it only allows this to work if the pointer is a const. How would I then change this pointer later on using pointer arithmetic if it is a const? I've tried declaring the pointer and doing the pointer arithmetic all in one but then I get a warning indicating that the data types are different, even though I'm using all const pointers in the arithmetic. Is there something I'm missing that would make this easier?
i_answer: As the student suggests, if you are just returning an address of your mat->data array, the compiler will automatically convert this to a const int pointer. If you are directly returning a mat->data element in your non-const Matrix_at, you will be able to copy the implementation. If you are saving off your pointer and returning a local variable, make sure that local variable that you are returning is a const int *.

subject: Memory Leak
content: My partner and I tried to run our tests for matrix, but it states there's a memory leak, and we can't find the source even after stepping through the debugger. We made sure to delete the matrix in the test function and only initialize once. Here are screenshots of the error:. .
i_answer: 2 things, both of which you can definitely fix ~~and one which might be a bit weirder:~~. . 1. Double-check your pointer arithmetic in `Matrix_at` (both versions). However, based on your current implementations I think `test_fill_basic` at least should be passing. ~~Which leads me to the second point:~~. . ~~2. can you try renaming one of the variables called `mat` to `mat1` or something similar? Basically don't use the same name across different tests. If that works please let us know.~~. . 2. on line 90, you are comparing to the address of the variable declared on line 78. This is not consistent. The way you should use `Matrix_row` and `Matrix_col` is to get the address of an element in `mat`, then pass that into those functions. This is why the second test case is failing - there is an error in how the test is written.. . ~~Still looking into the memory leak.~~. . Think I found the reason for the memory leaks - your tests fail before you `delete mat`, so that part of the code is never reached and your memory leaks. When I try them out and change the tests so that they pass, I don't get the leaks. I think what you could do is create a matrix locally (without using `new`) and pass in the address of that matrix using the `&` operator.

subject: compute energy edge cases
content: How should we compute the energy of a matrix that is only made of borders. For example if a 2x2 matrix is passed in, wouldn't you not be able to calculate the energy because there is no N,S,E,W and only border pixels.
i_answer: Per the student followup, a correct 2x2 matrix will consist of only border pixels, which per the specifications for `compute_energy_matrix` should be left as 0 (because that would be the maximum energy found after computing the energy for each non-border pixel).

subject: Undo Partnership on Autograder
content: Is it possible to break a partnership on the autograder?
i_answer: You may change partners between projects. You may not change partners during a project. In exceptional cases, you may request partnership dissolution via email to the faculty. If the dissolution is granted, both partners may use previously shared code and both partners must work alone on the remainder of the project.. . https://eecs280.org/syllabus.html#project-partnerships.

subject: Error with const matrix_at
content: I keep getting the error "Cannot initialize a variable of type 'const int *' with an rvalue of type 'long'" when attempting to assign the pointer in the const Matrix_at. What does type 'long' indicate, and how would I go about fixing this?
i_answer: `long` is another type of number (like `int`, `short`, `double`, etc.). I've seen this a couple of times with students doing pointer arithmetic - this is probably something with your hardware and not because of anything you're doing incorrectly. What I've told students is just do . . ```(int)()```. . and that should be fine.. . In your case I would also say: doing that by itself won't make your type compatible with `const int *` because `int` is not the same as `int *`. (Depending on what exactly you're doing the `const` part should handle itself?)

subject: What does "Check respecting Matrix and Image interfaces" on autograder mean?
content: Hi, just a quick question what . " Check respecting Matrix and Image interfaces in processing.cpp" and similar phrases on autograder really mean. . Would love an explanation on this and how we should implement this?. . Thanks!
i_answer: To add onto the student's answer, there is more detail about what respecting the interfaces should look like in project 2 on the spec. Essentially, you should only be directly accessing member variables of the Image struct within your implementation of Image itself, and same for Matrix, etc. On the outside, you should be making use of the getter functions you write such as Matrix_width instead of trying to do mat->width directly.

subject: How to compute "energy" in processing.cpp
content: So for the function "computer_energy_matrix" in processing.cpp, we need to "Compute the energy for each non-border pixel" . I can see that for this particular 5x5 image, the energies are the following values. However, how do I find the energies of a fresh image that currently has an empty energy matrix?
i_answer: As per the spec:. . To construct the energy Matrix for the whole image, your function should do the following:. . 1. Initialize the energy Matrix with the same size as the Image and fill it with zeros.. 2. Compute the energy for each non-border pixel, using the formula above.. 3. Find the maximum energy so far, and use it to fill in the border pixels. . So first you initialize the energy matrix and fill it with zeros. Then use this formula to compute the energy for each entry in the matrix:. `energy(X) = squared_difference(N, S) + squared_difference(W, E)`

subject: setprecision()
content: Does setprecision(20) mean that we’re rounding up the number for twenty decimal places?
i_answer: set precision sets the number of decimal places to print for a floating point value, i.e.: . . . double x = 3.141592;. std::cout << std::setprecision(2); . std::cout << x << std::endl;. std::cout << std::setprecision(5);. std::cout << x << std::endl;. would print:. 3.1. 3.1416. . does that help?. . (https://cplusplus.com/reference/iomanip/setprecision/)

subject: Matrix Row and Column
content: For the matrix row and column value that we return in Matrix_row and Matrix_column, are we returning an int value as if we are indexing (starting the rows/column number at 0) or regularly (starting at 1)?
i_answer: Matrix_row and Matrix_column should return row/column values starting at zero. This should match Matrix_at(), which takes zero-based row/column numbers as input.

I'd suggest using your debugger and stepping through the "dog remove seam" tests and stepping into your functions in order to see where the error is being thrown. the lines under the "read of size 4" part (e.g. image.cpp 66, processing_public_tests.cpp 246) should give you hints about where to check as well.. . the allocated/freed is telling you that you where you allocated the memory, and where it became undefined (free)

Image_public_test.exe: Matrix.cpp:79: int* Matrix_at(Matrix*, int, int): Assertion `0 <= row && row < mat->height' failed.Aborted. . I do not know how my row and cols got messed up, but any type of help would be appreciated.
i_answer: it means that somewhere in your image.cpp you're indexing out of bounds in your matrix (i.e. row is less than 0 or greater than height). would recommend stepping through your code to find exactly where as the student suggested!

subject: Tips for Test Cases
content: I've been struggling to expose the bugs for Matrix.cpp and Image.cpp. Is there specific functions where the bugs are, or specific cases I should think about?
i_answer: When I think about test cases, I think about what could break my implementation. Typically any function that has a loop of some sort (while, for) are broken by out of bounds errors. Look at how you implemented your functions and think about what out of bounds errors could occur. Also think about size of the data. Will a larger number or a larger amount of data impact the results? . . This is a great question! I am sure others would find the information useful. If you feel comfortable, would you mind making this post public so other students can read it? You can mark your name as Anonymous if you want!. . Hope this helps!

subject: "c style string" for resize
content: In the spec, it says for us to use c-style strings when processing command line arguments. Why is this mentioned as a requirement when automatically, the elements in argv[] are all c-style strings? Am I missing something?
i_answer: Nope, you're not missing anything. That part in the spec implies that you need to use argv to create the command line prompt for resize.

subject: What is the point of having the int* and const int* versions of matrix_at?
content: What is the point of having the int* and const int* versions of matrix_at?
i_answer: One is for changing the matrix, the other is for accessing the matrix and it has compatibility with function calls that pass in a constant matrix. It's good practice because it will help prevent us from changing a matrix when we don't want to.

subject: ssh key setup not working
content: Hello! I set up an SSH key earlier in order to skip password authentication every time I try to push to GitLab. I followed the set up and pasted my SSH key on my GitLab account, but even after I have it, GitLab is still prompting for my password.. . My GitLab account is authenticated with my UMICH profile, so the password is set. For context the prompt is:. . git@gitlab.eecs.umich.edu's password: . . but everytime I have tried to enter in my password, I received: . Permission denied, please try again.. . Multiple people have tried to enter my password and it hasn't worked, which is why I tried setting up the SSH keys, which isn't working either. Can anyone help (either a how-to on resetting the GitLab password or how check to see if the SSH key is working)? Thanks!
i_answer: Check to see if your ssh agent has the right credentials.. . ```console. eval "$(ssh-agent -s)". ssh-add -l. ```. . If you don't see anything there, make sure you've done all the steps at https://docs.github.com/en/authentication/connecting-to-github-with-ssh/generating-a-new-ssh-key-and-adding-it-to-the-ssh-agent.. . Or, if that's not the issue, please feel free to follow-up.

subject: Error in tests
content: Hi, . . Can I have help with the following error. I am working with the function: find_minimal_cost_seam(). It seems to not run because of an out of bounds error. I'm also confused a bit by the spec. Is the seam at a certain row equal to the minimum of the three pixels above or below it?. . Thanks. . .
i_answer: So for find\_minimal\_vertical\_seam you're working from bottom of the matrix to the top. Seam is an array, so each item in seam corresponds to the minimum cost pixel for that row. . . To find the minimum cost pixel at any row `i`, you choose the minimum index of the 3 values in the row above it, as shown in the diagram. It's easy to get out of bounds errors here since at each end of the matrix, there will only be 2 values to choose from. You should also consider that there is no row **above** row 0.. ![image.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fkeeutacclj53vw%2Fc8878176eb5b84a334bd152eebb456544537dd766b48594dae54c58258bb206d%2Fimage.png)

I am printing the column size in my Matrix_at() function because it is asserting that the column parameter is larger than the matrix parameter. This was the output. I am putting the print function at the top of my matrix_at() function so it is not even reaching my code. Any hints on how to fix this?
i_answer: Well, you likely have an infinite for loop or while loop, I would look at all your loops for where this might be happening first.

subject: Incompatible integer to pointer conversion
content: Hi i have an error saying "Incompatible integer to pointer conversion assigning to 'int *' from 'int'", and i am not quite sure what's going on...
i_answer: `row * (mat->width) + column` ends up being an `int` value, but `ptr` itself is an `int *` type. These are not the same - `int *` is an address while `int` is just a number.

subject: about matrix_at
content: Hi i have a few questions about Matrix_at:. . 1. which pointer are we looking at? Is it mat? Do i need to create a ptr myself?. 2. I know how to do the arithmetic to transform 2d-1d index but a pointer's value is an address, how do i edit that? I know that i can use row and column and width/height to get the 1d index, but after that what kind of command should i use to get the address of that object and let our ptr point to it?????. 3.What's the difference between. . int* Matrix_at(Matrix* mat, int row, int column). . and. . const int* Matrix_at(const Matrix* mat, int row, int column). . like, what do they mean by pointer-to-const?. . I am so unfamilier with c++....Geez this is so hard for me.... . Thank you !!!. .
i_answer: 1. From the RME of the function, "mat points to a valid Matrix", "Returns a pointer to the element in the Matrix at the given row and column". So max is given (data type: Matrix *), but what you want to return is a pointer that points to an element in the Matrix (data type: int *).. 2. I recommend checking lab 3 again. Remember the elements of an array are stored contiguously in memory. In other words, they are next to each other. So if a pointer points to the first element, what is the thing that the pointer (pointer+1) points to? You may do the math and find the pointer that points to the wanted element.. 3. Here is a link to the note of EECS 280 which explains what const is.. . Pointers are definitely difficult (and important). Project 2 is designed to give you a better idea of what are pointers, and how they work, so don't worry too much if you get confused at first sight.

subject: Matrix_at type error with const int* and const int
content: We're getting this error when my partner try to compile Matrix_at. . . We are dividing a const int* by a const int, and were wondering if it is a problem with the / symbol, or if we just need our types to both be const int or both const int*.
i_answer: Remember that the value of a point is an address, and an address is something like 0xbfdb70f0. Think about why division or multiplication does not make sense for addresses (The start address of an array is not necessarily 0x0, and it can change every time you run your project.), but we can do additions and subtractions (with some limits).

subject: Perf Mac Equivalent
content: When submitting to autograder my program keeps timing out on horses, due to this I am trying to find the inefficient part of my project, the spec suggests we use perf to find this. However, after researching, perf is only available on linux, are there any suggestions for what I can do if I am on mac?
i_answer: In addition to the student answers, it looks like there are equivalent tools on macOS ->https://stackoverflow.com/questions/23200704/install-perf-on-mac. For students on windows, you should still be able to install perf and then run the program from the base folder. . . A couple things to check: Matrix_at gets called multiple times throughout the program; are you looping to find this value? Try also removing the assert statements when running your program; they can be helpful for debugging, but they can cause your program to slow down if you are doing a check for every single pixel multiple times throughout the process.

subject: When are we allowed to use mat-> to access the struct directly?
content: I'm under the impression that within Matrix.cpp we can only use mat->data in four functions. Namely, Matrix_row, matrix_column and both Matrix_at. Additionally, we should only use mat->width/height in Matrix_width and Matrix_height. In all other cases we should be calling the previous functions (Matrix_at/width/height) to accomplish the task. Is this correct, or do we have freedom to use mat-> wherever we want within Matrix.cpp?
i_answer: For structs, the members are public by default. That means you can always do mat->width, but this doesn't mean it is good practice trying to get the members directly (later in the class, you will see why we need class which solved this issue to some extent).. I think in your Matrix.cpp whenever you need to get the width, feel free to use either mat->width or Matrix_width. Outside Matrix.cpp, it is better practice to just use Matrix_width. Same for the height. You may notice whenever you use mat->width, you have the ability to write the value (the write permission could be dangerous sometimes), but with Matrix_width, you can only read the width but cannot write the value (safer when you only need to read).

subject: When/how to use xyz_public_test files?
content: Hi,. . I was wondering at what stage in the project we should use the public_test files for Matrix, Image and processing. Is there a way to run them all together with a single command?. . Thanks,. Muskaan
i_answer: `make test` in the command line will compile and run all your tests in sequence, including the public test files and your private tests. You should rely primarily on your own private test cases and use the public tests as a sanity check.. . Do note that we provide tests for matrix and image printing which we do not expect you to implement on your own.

subject: RME in cpp files
content: Just a quick style question, are we allowed to delete the RME from the cpp files once we finish the functions in order to clean up the code?
i_answer: We do not recommend doing that since RME is actually good style (rather than messing up the code). Leaving proper explanations of what a function does is helpful for future maintenance.

I am doing the image.cpp. It indeed passed the given Image_public_tests.cpp. However, the autograder threw an error saying 'struct Matrix has no members data, width, height' in the check for respecting Matrix interface in Image.cpp. Can anyone figure out why is this case?. . . .
i_answer: To get the width of any matrix, you should be using the functions you've implemented in `Matrix.cpp` to access those values. Try to avoid calling `.width` on the rgb matrix channels so you're respecting the interface!

subject: os in Matrix_print() Function

Edit: I did some research and since "cout" is an object of "ostream", when we call Matrix_print(), the second parameter of Matrix_print() would be "cout", correct?
i_answer: ostream works like cout similar to how istream can be a replacement for cin when reading in a file (so you can just print to os like os << "hello!". Yes, if you wanted to call Matrix_print() somewhere in your code and print to console, you would pass in cout..

subject: Xcode error

i_answer: Do you see this error if you manually run "make Image_tests.exe" from the terminal? If so, make sure you don't have more than one main() function in your P2 code (in resize.cpp), and that you aren't including any .cpp files -- you want to define each function once in a .cpp file, and include it everywhere else using only the .h file it's declared in. Hope this helps!

For the two errors you mentioned, which one is checked first? If that error was triggered, what the program should do? Will it even check the potential second error?

subject: Matrix fill
content: Would I use a nested for loop for the matrix fill and matrix fill border functions?
i_answer: No you do not need nested for loop. Think about what is the data structure that "data" uses. Is it 2-dimensional?. We introduced that you may move pointers by doing some math so the pointers point to some other elements in the array. You may want to apply the idea here.

subject: array passed to function
content: When I passed seam[] to the find seam function, it seemed that seam is not passed as an array, and every change I made on other elements of seam array did not work. As is shown in the list of variables, there is only a "*seam".. Even if I assign *seam with 1, the point is, the array seems to lose its size. In the main function, it was assigned with size 500, but when passed into the function, it only shows one space with value 0, and doesn't change anymore. For example, while I'm debugging, in the main function , the seam is shown as an array with size 500:.When I step into the function, the seam changed.Even when I try to assign"seam[0] = 1;seam[1] = 2;", nothing changed,there still shows"*seam = 0"
i_answer: This should be fine. Basically when you pass the array into the function, you don't pass in any information to indicate how long it is. Because of that, the debugger cannot assume that your array is of length 500, and so it defaults to just showing the dereference of the first element. . . Note that when you pass in the array like this, array decay occurs and you really get an `int *`. So all the debugger can assume it has in this state is a pointer, not the entire array. Does that make sense?

subject: Creating Matrix
content: When we want to access the matrix struct for functions like print, init, width, height, etc.. Do we have to use . . Matrix* mat = new Matrix;. everytime?.
i_answer: You shouldn’t have to use the `new` keyword at all in `Matrix.cpp` or `Image.cpp`! To initialize a new matrix, make sure you’re calling `Matrix_init()` and passing in the appropriate Matrix pointer.

subject: matrix max const
content: currently working on matrix max, iterating thru data 1d array to find the max value. but because the matrix is a const, i can't do it the way i am used to, since i can't assign a variable(max) to a value of data. if i make max (the variable) a const, i can't change it later if i find a higher value. am i missing something simple?
i_answer: A very common "max" algorithm is to keep track of the largest value you have seen so far:. .     if(example[i]>max){.       max = example[i];.     }. . You'll have to initialize max to some value, typically either a really low value (negative, so like -2000000000), or to the first value of the array, and then subtract one from that value. You won't need to modify the matrix at all, and max can be overwritten (max is not a const).

subject: Image_init and Image_print
content: Hello,. . I have 2 questions about the image.cpp file. For my image_init file, I have been doing img->red_channel.data[i], but reading the spec again, I am not allowed to do that. I tried to do Matrix_at for this, but then I got stuck on trying to figure out the row and col parameters.. . My second question is about the for loop in image_print. I'm pretty sure we have to do a nested for loop with width and height, but I do not know how to progress past that. Any help would be appreciated.
i_answer: So for your first question, as it is mainly a syntax question, I will just give you the syntax answer:. . Matrix_init(&img->red_channel, width, height);. Now, I think they actually gave us this line to use in the specs, but in the first Image_init, I want to remind you that you are just initializing the width and height of the image, and all of its matrices. You will use this syntax a lot in many functions, specifically &img->red_channel.. . For question 2, I would suggest writing Image_get_pixel first, and then using that for the output of three different parts of the pixel to the ostream (but the 2D for loop is right, good job!)

subject: How do I fix memory leaks that occur in the LeakSanitizer?
content: The UB checks on the autograder say that my code has a memory leak every time I do something like `Pixel *pixel = new Pixel;` and I'm not sure how to fix that (since I do need to instantiate a new object). Would I need to delete the objects at some point to fix this or what should I do?. . Additionally, the leak sanitizer won't work since my compiler claims it does not support `-fsanitize=leak`, so how should I go about looking for memory leak issues?
i_answer: To clarify: any time you use the `new` keyword, you will need to use the `delete` keyword on the object you allocated once you are done using it, to ensure all memory allocated is deallocated, and nothing is leaked.

subject: Matrix print
content: May we use loop function on matrix_print?.
i_answer: Using for loops for something like Matrix_print is perfectly fine! You have to access/print every element of the matrix for this function, so doing it with a for loop makes a lot of sense.. . For function like Matrix_at, Matrix_row, Matrix_column, you really only care about a single element of the matrix, so we just want to warn that using a for loop for these functions is not necessary and will potentially cause slow runtime.

subject: Using Matrix_test_helpers
content: After writing a plethora of tests, I am a little bit unclear about how to use the Matrix_test_helper functions. Is it required to use these? I am specifically confused as to how the Matrix_equal one would be useful. Would we have to create two Matrices at once? And what would the array_equal one do if this interface of the matrix really being an array is abstracted away from the user anyway and we have to respect the interface in the test file?
i_answer: You are definitely not required to use these functions, you are more than welcome to though if you want. . . To use Matrix_equal, you would have to create two Matrices: one that you're testing on and one that has your expected output.. . We primarily use Array_equal to test seams for processing. This would probably be the only scenario I would use it in.

Full terminal output:. . . sgl@Seung-Gus-MacBook-Pro eecs280-p2-cv % ./processing_public_tests.exe. Testing dog rotate left...PASS. Testing dog rotate right...PASS. Testing dog energy...PASS. Testing dog cost...PASS. Testing dog find seam...PASS. Testing dog remove seam...PASS. Testing dog seam carve 4x5...PASS. dog tests PASS. . Testing crabster rotate left...PASS. Testing crabster rotate right...PASS. Testing crabster energy...PASS. Testing crabster cost...PASS. Testing crabster find seam...PASS. Testing crabster remove seam...PASS. Testing horses energy...Assertion failed: (Matrix_equal(energy_mat, energy_mat_correct)), function test_energy, file processing_public_tests.cpp, line 135.. zsh: abort      ./processing_public_tests.exe. sgl@Seung-Gus-MacBook-Pro eecs280-p2-cv % ./processing_public_tests.exe. Testing dog rotate left...PASS. Testing dog rotate right...PASS. Testing dog energy...PASS. Testing dog cost...PASS. Testing dog find seam...PASS. Testing dog remove seam...PASS. Testing dog seam carve 4x5...PASS. dog tests PASS. . Testing crabster rotate left...PASS. Testing crabster rotate right...PASS. Testing crabster energy...PASS. Testing crabster cost...PASS. It would be the equivalent of getting lucky.

subject: matrix border fill edge case question
content: Two separate questions below:. . When there is a matrix that only has one row, do I only fill in the far right and far left side columns with the specified variable?. . When there is a matrix that only has two rows, do I only fill in the far right and far left side columns with the specified variable on both rows?
i_answer: No you'd just fill the whole thing up in any thing that has 2 or less for a height or width value.

subject: What is matrix_print supposed to print exactly?
content: I am very confused by the rme of matrix_print. I get the first line, but the second line makes no sense to me. What does "print the rows of the matrix to os with one row per line. each element is followed by a space and each row is followed by a new line." mean? . . The matrix public test did not seem to help me too much. Why does it call matrix_at? I thought someone said to implement the functions in order so how are we supposed to do matrix_print? . . I just don't necessarily get what is supposed to be printed out.
i_answer: So, lets say we had a matrix like this:. . . What do we want to print?. We want to print the following (2 2 is width and height of the matrix):. 2 2. 1 2 . 3 5. . Now, it may be unclear where the spaces are, so I'll make it more clear. Here, a "_" means a space:. 2_2. 1_2_. 3_5_. . Also I don't know who said to implement them in order, Matrix_at is very useful in this. You'll need a 2D for loop that goes through the row and column dimensions, using Matrix_at to retrieve the value at that entry, then give that to the output stream.

i_answer: Soo... the answer to this is a little complicated. In this one, you are going to actually read in all of the data and stuff from a .ppm. See @781 for some tips for how to do that. In case you want some more hints, here you go:. You will probably want to use a temp Pixel variableYou will want to use the Image_set_pixel functionYou will want to use the other Image_init function inside of the Image_init functionYou'll want a 2D for loopYou'll really want to use the tip in @781

subject: compute_energy_matrix question
content: For the compute_energy_matrix function, let's say I have a 3 x 1 matrix (3 rows and 1 column). What would happen then since there's no index where the element is a "non-border" element? How would the energy matrix look like?
i_answer: This situation would end up with all entries having a value of zero. However, even though it is not explicitly said, this case should never happen.

subject: completely lost on image_init
content: I can't figure out how to use an istream passed in through image_init and read it, the instructors said somewhere else to create a separate istream object with the same name but I don't know how that even works. How do I even get all the individual numbers using cin? I tried looking through the lecture notes but it just prints out each individual word I don't know where it's stored.
i_answer: As the student response mentions, you can essentially treat an istream object like it is a cin and read in input using the >> operator. Instead of getting input from the user from the standard input device (like a keyboard), istream takes information from an existing file and feeds it into your program, as if it was coming in via cin.. . And it is pretty magical! You don’t really have to worry about spacing, new lines, etc. - your program will know where you last left off in reading in info, so you can pick right off the next time you use >>..

subject: -> pointers
content: Can someone kind of explain how we use -> with pointers?
i_answer: You can think of the -> operator as equivalent to dereferencing a pointer and then using the . operator to access a member of the object being pointed to.. . In other words, ptr->x is equivalent to (*ptr).x. .

subject: init  function purpose ?
content: Hey , So with the init function am I trying to just make a blank array that will serve as a blank matrix of the specified dimensions. If so what is the purpose of the pointer.. . Or am I making it so that the pointer given is the address of the first element in our blank array therefore matrix that will be constructed using the dimensions provided. . . Or is it something else .. . Pls help.
i_answer: The init function just takes in the already made matrix and sets its width and height in the matrix struct. That's it, just like 2 lines of code.. . In general, what you'll have is some code in a different file altogether that says the following:. Matrix* mat = new Matrix;. int width = 5;. int height = 6;. Matrix_init(mat, width, height);.... .... delete mat;

subject: mat.size
content: Would a matrix.size() be allowed or even work
i_answer: The only elements of a Matrix struct that are accessible with a . operator are width, height, and the data array.. . Since there is no size function defined for the matrix struct, matrix.size() would not work.. . As the student follow up suggests, the width and height of a matrix are set in Matrix_init, and should be returned in the Matrix_width and Matrix_height functions respectively.

subject: set up for project two
content: After adding my files to my xcode project, there are "A"'s next to the file names. I've never seen these icons before. What do they mean?
i_answer: This is XCode integrating with the Git version control system that you set up with the project 2 version control tutorials. . . "A" next to a file means that the file was added to your version control system and did not exist before. You may also see "M" for modified if you made changes to a file that were not seen by Git, or "C" if there is a conflict between your local file and what exists on GitLab.. . If you are interested, here is a list of the possible svn status codes and what they correspond to.

subject: Understanding pointer
content: I am having trouble understanding some stuff about the matrix.. First if we are given const Matrix* mat in a function. How do I pull, I should be able to pull for example the first piece of data by doing mat->data[0] right? if not how do am i suposed to pull data correctly.. Second in this screenshot am i calling any of the pointer incorrectly?.
i_answer: You are correct that mat->data[index] is how you access the Matrix element stored at a given index in the data array.. . The goal of the Matrix_column function is to find this index that ptr points to in the data array, and convert it to a column in the matrix.. . The spec urges you not to use any loops to determine the column. Instead, I would think of it in the following steps:. . 1) Find the index in the data array that corresponds to the element pointed to by ptr. 2) Determine a formula to convert from the index in the data array to the corresponding column that element would be in for the matrix

subject: Project runtime
content: Hello,. . in my matrix.cpp module, I never make a new matrix and simply manipulate the individual elements within mat, using a for loop. I believe this works, but if given a large matrix, I believe that my code will be very slow. Does how fast our code matter in project 2? If so, will making a new matrix make my code a lot faster? Thanks :)
i_answer: You shouldn't need to allocate any dynamic memory (use new/delete) in Matrix.cpp. You can also see this reiterated in the RME for Matrix_init in Matrix.h. Manipulating the individual elements, using for loops, etc. should be sufficient. If you are concerned about runtime, I would just make sure you don't have any unnecessary for-loops or other logic.. . In general, we don't worry much about time complexity of your code in this class; that's something you would focus on in EECS 281. That said, I have seen students have issues with runtime for resize on larger files (ie. horses) because their lower-level logic in Matrix/Image is unnecessarily complex. I have also seen students with memory issues on these larger files because they did use new/delete in their Matrix/Image implementations. My advice is to just be sure your logic for the Matrix/Image functions is as simple as you can make it, but also don't stress about runtime unless it is becoming a problem. If it is, we are happy to help during Office Hours!

subject: test cases not deleting previous matrix
content: I am writing test cases for matrix.cpp, and my test case for matrix_fill_border is failing only because the values I'm not filling are taking data from the matrix i created in my previous test case. I added a "delete matrix;" line at the end of my previous test case but the data in those indexes is still carrying over into my next test case. The matrixes have different names and sizes so I have no clue why its doing that and why the previous matrix isn't deleting. Any ideas would be appreciated!!
i_answer: Hello!. . If your new operator has a corresponding delete operator in your previous test case, the previous matrix should be getting deleted! . . It is always good practice to set ALL the values in your current test matrix to a certain value to prevent a sort of default initialization of values from taking place.  . . After you fill your test matrix with a certain value, you can then proceed to test your matrix_fill_border : )

subject: PPM requires check
content: I'm a bit confused as to how we can assert whether an image is in ppm format without comments. Or is there no assert and we can naturally assume that this requirement will be true?
i_answer: In EECS 280, you can assume the requires clause of a function will never be violated -- that is, the autograder won't try any inputs that break the requires clause.. It's still good practice to assert requires clauses, but asserting the PPM format is a bit tricky to do meaningfully. A simple check would be to assert the first line of the file is "P3," to indicate it's a "plain PPM file." You could also check that none of the numerical values are negative, and the color intensities don't exceed the specified maximum (which is always 255). Of course, this doesn't promise the entire file is correctly formatted, but I wouldn't worry about robustly checking this invariant.

subject: testing Image_init using dog.ppm etc
content: Hi,. . How can I test Image_init with the various .ppm files? Which stream/syntax would I use for this? Or is this something that will come in processing/resize.cpp and should not be done directly from Image_test.cpp?. . Essentially how do I pass a .ppm as a parameter to the istream in Image_init
i_answer: You may want to look into creating an ifstream object with the name of the .ppm file, and passing it into Image_init. If you don't want to read in an entire file, you can also create an istringstream object, and pass in your own made-up PPM data as a string. Hope this helps!. . Edit: You should only be using stringstream objects (like istringstream and ostringstream) and not ifstream/ofstream. The autograder may not recognize the files you're trying to read in with fstream, so don't use it in your tests.

content: How do we use the helper functions in Matrix_test_helpers.h in Matrix_tests.cpp if we can't directly fill in data[] from Matrix_tests.cpp? Wouldn't this just result in comparing a matrix to itself as we would have to individually fill in the values of both matrices?. . Thanks,. Muskaan

I'm not entirely sure what you mean when you say "comparing a matrix to itself as we would have to individually fill in the values of both matrices", so please correct me if I misinterpreted your question : ) . . For any test case, you have an expected answer (which you hardcode). As you said, you can't directly fill in data[] in Matrix_tests.cpp but you have implemented various functions in Matrix.cpp that might help you with this!  Given the objective of test cases as discussed in labs and lectures, you would then want to check if the expected answer matches what your test case is returning.. . The Matrix_test_helpers has two functions. I would encourage you to read the RMEs of each in the Matrix_test_helpers.h file to see how they can help compare your expected values with your actual values!.

subject: string library not working?
content: I did #include <string> so that I could declare string variables, but I am still getting an error stating: 'identifier "string" is undefined'. . . . Also, do we need to do anything with the P3 at the top of ppm files, and are there any examples of reading input from an I/O stream like is? Thank you!
i_answer: Do `using namespace std;`. . You don't need to do anything with the P3, but you have to assume it will be there as the first line in any ppm file.. . An example of outputting to an `ostringstream` (a type of `ostream`) is in `Matrix_public_tests.cpp`, but in reality they work the same way as `cin/cout`. The way you're doing it in the screenshot is fine.

subject: Row and column indexing
content: For the matrix_row and matrix_column functions, do we start indexing the rows and column from 0 or 1? For example if we have a 3x3 matrix. {1, 2, 3. 4, 5, 6,. 7, 8, 9}. and we have ptr pointing to 8, would matrix_row(ptr) return 3 or 2? Would matrix_column(ptr) return 2 or 1? I have a similar question for matrix_width and matrix_height. If it was a 3x3 matrix would they return 3 and 3 or 2 and 2? In the public tests it seems to be that matrix_row and matrix_column are indexed from 1..
i_answer: Both rows and columns are always indexed starting from 0. . . In your example, Matrix_row would return 2 and Matrix_column would return 1 (for a pointer to the 8).. However, Matrix_width and Matrix_height would both be 3, because there are 3 elements in each row and 3 elements in each column (you actually count these).

subject: Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row edge case
content: Will this function not work for matrices with only one column? One of the requires statements is that column_start < column_end. This implies there must be at least two columns for this function to work. Will we not receive any matrices with only one column or is it a case we should not consider?
i_answer: Remember that column_end is the column one PAST the one you want to end at (so it's non-inclusive). So column_start could be 0 and column_end could be 1 in a matrix with only one column.

subject: Having a hard time to start matrix.cpp
content: Hi I'm really having a hard time to start this project...I feel like i am so unfamiliar with C++ syntax and pointer that i don't really know where to start....I went to the supplemental tutorial and it made a lot of sense to me...but still...
i_answer: Let's start with the Matrix_init function. This function takes in a pointer to a Matrix object (the first parameter) - this is the Matrix object that we are initializing. We're given a width and a height, and all we want to do in Matrix_init is set mat's width and height. Remember that with pointers, you have to use arrow syntax to access its member variables (ie. mat->width). Instead of setting width and height to 500, you want to set it to the width and height that are passed into the function. Does that help? . . The rest of the functions follow a similar pattern. You're always given "mat," which is a pointer to the object you'll be working with. For example, in Matrix_width, you want to return mat's width. Recall the definition for the Matrix struct (in Matrix.h):. . struct Matrix{.   int width;.   int height;.   int data[MAX_MATRIX_WIDTH * MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT];. };. You can use arrow syntax with the mat pointer to return the width member variable of the Matrix object.. . It would also really help to watch/review the lectures on pointers and arrays, and make sure you have a solid understanding of how they work. I would really recommend the Runestone async lectures.

subject: how to test matrix print using unit testing
i_answer: There's an example in Matrix_public_test.cpp (test_matrix_print). Essentially you create an ostringstream for your expected output and then an ostringstream for your actual output (pass this into your Matrix_print function), then compare those two using .str()

content: I'm using a for loop in one of the functions for matrix.cpp but I get an error when I try to test it.  . . function(Matrix * mat, int index, int x){. for(index; index < x; ++index){//error line. implementation where y is derived using index.   }. return y. }. there isn't a squiggly line anywhere but when I try to compile I get. error: expression result unused [-Werror,-Wunused-value]. The error in the command line shows squiggles under the first "index" in the for loop.. Why doesn't this work? I figured since the index would be declared as an int and given a value when the function is called that the for loop should continue as normal, I played around with it in lobster and this seemed to work.
i_answer: Try just doing "for(; index < x; ++index)"

subject: How can we make assign a Matrix with values that are not the same (like 1,2,3,4)?
content: I want to make a Matrix with values 1,2,3,4 in a 2x2 matrix for my test functions. I tried to assign values using "->" but this does not respect the Matrix interface. Is there another way to assign these values or initialize Matrix with them?
i_answer: You can use the Matrix_at() function, for exmaple, if you wanted to set the the value at row 0 and column 0 to one, it would be something like:. . . *Matrix_at(mat, 0, 0) = 1;. . . - Remember that Matrix_at() returns a pointer, so we have to use the dereference operator (*) before we set it to a value

subject: should i  do processing or image after matrix?
i_answer: Image :). . For other people who may see this, the best order is: Matrix.cpp -> Image.cpp -> Processing.cpp -> resize.cpp. . But if you ever get stuck on something, try to move on to the next parts to save some time

subject: Is it possible to compare two ostringstreams to see if they are equal?
i_answer: Yes, if you do something like: . . . ostringstream correct;. correct << (print whatever you expect to be printed here);. ostringstream actual;. Matrix_print(mat, actual); //actual will get printed inside print function. ASSERT_EQUAL(correct.str(), actual.str());.

subject: autograder running into std::bad_alloc while grading?
content: The autograder is running into `std::bad_alloc` (cannot allocate memory) while grading my submission for horses. Does this mean I'm doing something wrong (or need to use less memory) or does the autograder not have enough memory to perform the test?
i_answer: I'm almost certain it's because you implemented your Matrix_column() and Matrix_row() functions with for loops. Both of these functions should be written without a loop (keeping in mind this is very possible since we are dealing with a 1D array in matrix.cpp). . Horses is a really big image so a lot of memory issues do tend to come up here

subject: martix_at
content: no instance of overloaded function "Matrix_at" matches the argument list. Does this mean my actual matrix_at function is wrong or am i calling it into a pointer wrong?. . .
i_answer: `Matrix_at` returns a `[const] int *` type, whereas since `pr` is a pointer, `*pr` is of type `int`. So it's a type mismatch.
